Reviews.Title: Excellent camera with a couple of drawbacks
Reviews.Author: Inspector Gadget "Go Go Gadget Reviews"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera over a year ago to replace my Samsung HMX-R10 and it works brilliantly as a movie-making camera and as a still camera. Naturally, as there is a focus ring the D3200 is not focused to infinity so when you're lining up your shots, be it video or stills, you will need to take a bit of extra time. This wouldn't be such a hassle if there was a pop-out reversible screen (as featured on the Nikon D5100 model) but there isn't, which means if you are out shooting on your own and want yourself to be in the shot then you are going to run into many logistical problems. Quite annoying, but it's my only real gripe with this model. There IS auto-focus, naturally, but you can't be sure that you're actually in the shot and in position without a reversible screen.The quality of the pics, at 24.2 megapixels, is amazing, with very deep colors and bold contrast. When loaded onto your computer you can zoom-in many times without losing resolution. It's great. There are a few picture editing tools but I've never really experimented with them as I prefer my shots to look as natural as possible. The long-exposure feature is capable of creating night shots with amazing light effects.The video can record in 24fps, which is a major plus if you want your movies to look as film-ic as possible. Obviously setting it to 1080p is the best option. I wish that it shot in 2k but simple 1080p is all that it offers. Still, the quality of the video image is excellent, and a huge improvement on simple camcorders.There is an audio-in jack for attaching externals mics, and a shoe on the top for securing it (or an auxiliary flash), but when taking pics the built-in flash will not fire properly with a mic loaded.The strap is a bit of a gamble. Twice now the clasps have given way when I've been carrying it around my shoulder. Luckily, I was quick enough to catch the camera in my hand, but it's just too heavy. I'd recommend using vinyl tape or staples to bind the cord and ensure that it does not come undone.The 18-55mm lens is pretty basic, and you will have to stand very close to anything that you want to shoot, but it works perfectly with the 52mm Wide-Angle Lens if you want a mini-IMAX feel to your shots, and can also be used with the AG-LA7200 Anamorphic Lens to frame your movies in full 2.35:1 widescreen. The stills have a native aspect ratio of 1.55:1 and will come out in 2:1 with an anamorphic attachment that has a 1.33:1 squeeze.The camera uses SCHD memory cards that are loaded into a little slot on the right of casing, but the door that closes over this slot feels a little flimsy. It's never once broken on me, but it's one of those things that once broken can never be repaired which means that a new camera is on the cards if it does snap off.A very good camera, despite the drawbacks I have listed, I'd recommend this camera to newbs and novices as it is very easy to get familiar with. I love the red color and can stop polishing it whenever I get it out. I don't want any marks or fingerprints. Just keep an eye on the strap.

Reviews.Title: Great upgrade from D40
Reviews.Author: Andrew Warner
Reviews.Content: I finally decided to upgrade from my D40. I figured having a camera and video camera in one would make it easier to take video of our kids, especially #3 who was sorely lacking in the video department compared to the first two. I was debating between the D5100 and the D3200. (The D5200 was just announced when I made the purchase and had forced the price of the D5100 down to about the same as the D3200). In the end, I decided the only thing I liked on the D5100 that wasn't on the D3200 was the swivel screen. And I figured the newer, higher megapixel sensor would make this one last longer before it was replaced with a newer model. Pretty soon the D5100 wasn't being sold by Amazon, so that sealed it since buying from Amazon would get me a free SD card, backpack, $100 off the 55-200 VR lens (also an upgrade from my non-VR 55-200) and 2% back plus downgrading from Prime shipping even netted me $3 to spend on Amazon Instant Video.Since getting it, I have loved it. I'd describe myself as an "advanced" novice photographer. The Guide option has been really helpful to get at some of the settings on the camera. Decided to go with the red body, and I kind of miss the texture of the black body, as the red is more smooth and "plasticy" feeling. But so far the red does make it stand out and easy to tell which one is mine among the crowd.The video by itself would probably get only 3 or 4 stars. It took some figuring to place the camera in AF-F mode to get the focusing right. For the first few I was pressing the shutter half way down to force the focusing. The sound of the focusing motor is noticeable most of the time. The shotgun hot shoe microphone might help with that according to some reviews of it. But having a single device that can do both has definitely made it possible to get more videos of the kids. Picture wise, the video has been fantastic.Definitely worth the price. Not sorry at all the I didn't go with the D5100.

Reviews.Title: D3200 Great for Both Beginners and Moderate Photographers
Reviews.Author: Chase
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera to get some professional quality photos at a reasonable price for a beginner. I must say that the D3200 well exceeded all my expectations for spending about $550 on the body as well as the kit lens. However, I will update this review over the life of the camera, so you can get an accurate review to make an informed decision.Let's begin...So far, the camera on auto is great, but it's true beauty lies when the user tries to mess around with the manual settings. I've been able to achieve some fantastic photo effects by changing the features from the shutter speed to the ISO settings.Based on my pictures (and one video) thus far, I can definitely say the following:1. Auto Mode is okay. Honestly though, if all the you want to do with a camera is take pictures on auto., then purchase a cheaper digital camera since you won't be utilizing the D3200's full potential... or any DSLR for that matter.2. The 18-55mm kit lens takes great pictures, but its certainly not professional quality; Let alone designed for professionals. I fully intend to learn the camera and master it's settings before committing to a more expensive (professional quality) lens, which can amount to quite an expensive sum.3. The video visual was amazing, but the video audio was not. The camera does have a external mic input, which I intend to take full advantage of. TIP: Make sure to purchase a class 6 memory card or higher or the video may turn out "laggish." I purchased a class 10.4. The 24.2 Megapixels was great if I wanted to crop without ruining the quality of the photo, otherwise it didn't make much (if any) difference when compared to 12ish megapixel photos.To sum up my experience, the D3200 is a great camera for beginners. I would even say the it's well suited for moderate level photographers if the camera isn't used on auto. mode. If anyone believes that they aren't getting great pictures, then I would say that the problem is most likely the photographer... not the camera itself. The camera truly does take fantastic pictures, yet it's less likely to happen on auto... and forget about professional quality with this 18-55mm lens. To truly take great pictures with this camera, you'll go far by going out one day to take a ton of pictures on various manual settings... then see for yourself what the effects are.

Reviews.Title: Much better than you expect of an “entry-level” camera.
Reviews.Author: Bob Blaylock
Reviews.Content: I own a Nikon F2 Photomic, made in 1971.  Forty years ago, this was Nikon's top-of-the-line camera.  Between my F2 and this D3200, I have a variety of much-lesser film and digital cameras.  I've long wished there was a digital back available for my F2, to convert it into a DSLR.  The advantages of digital photography over stone-aged film photography are tremendous, but nothing else that I had before the D3200 could take pictures nearly as good as what I could get with my F2.  This D3200 takes great pictures, easily in the same league as my old F2.  This is actually Nikon's current bottom-of-the-line (they prefer the term “entry-level”) DSLR, though quite a stock still seems to be out there, being sold in stores, of the now-obsolete predecessor to this camera, the D3100.  The experience of using it sure doesn't feel like what you expect of bottom-of-the-line.  It certainly does not feel like a step down in any way from my F2.  This camera seems to do an amazing job of striking a balance between the needs of the rankest novice, and those of the most experienced, discerning professional or skilled amateur.  It has fully-automated modes that implement an amazing degree of intelligence in determining the nature of the scene before it, and picking the optimal settings to photograph that scene,and it has fully-manual modes that allow the photographer to exercise complete control over every parameter.  Although the manual claims that non-AI lenses (any F-mount lenses made before 1977) cannot be used with this camera, I have found that all of my old non-AI lenses that I have for my F2 work just fine on this camera, albeit with some obvious and expected limitations.

Reviews.Title: New mom new camera
Reviews.Author: P. Saxon
Reviews.Content: Son was looking for a simple camera to take baby pictures and the 3200 was just released.  I read great reviews on photo mag and photo forums and so I ordered one.  The pictures are simply stunning with the 18-55mm lens and the 35mm lens I'd ordered. Youtube coverage also affected my choice.  It's an excellent camera.

Reviews.Title: Great camera - Entry level with Pro features.
Reviews.Author: Guru H "GH"
Reviews.Content: I started looking for a camera for less with lots of MP to replace my old D70, this one's got it.. 24MP and raw images are awesome, JPEG are great. I recently, left for a trip to India and took some 2000+ photos , bird sanctuaries, himalayas etc.. Photos were amazing, I will have to admit i used 70-200mm Nikkor lens (its about 2399). Photos were amazing. Live view is wonderful with 1080p HD vidoes camera does some wonderful things.. I wanted to buy D800, with are the reviews about focus issues , I have lost faith in Pro model from Nikon. This one is awesome. This little camera might not have all the features that D800 boasts about, but Hey, I can buy 4 3200's for the price of D800 and don't have to return to Nikon and wait with the tounge hanging out for it to return from repairs.Update -- 01/03/2013Now that the camera has been used for 6 months, buttons on the back are loose. Compression of images produces a pink bar on the Right hand side of the image. Continious frames are the cause of that pink bar. Its very prominent in RAW files and not much with JPEG.But i can live with it since, I crop my images. But that should not be happening. Next is Focus sometimes it misses it completely and try to focus on another focus point even though its not selected. Still, a good camera for the price. But, don't expect to work like a semi-pro. Will replace it with D7000. I know, D7000 is due its replacement. But,my rule of thumb is never buy something thats not tested. Expecially, when 600 and 800 has shown its ugly faces of oil spots and left focus issues respectively. Happy clicking.!!!!

Reviews.Title: Great Entry-Level DSLR Camera
Reviews.Author: Mycatdied
Reviews.Content: I definitely had a dilemma when it came to buying this camera.  One of the Top Selling Amazon dslr cameras was another competitor and so I naturally wanted to purchase that one, but after doing exhaustive research from various websites and critic reviews.  This camera has been rated as better over some of the closer competitors.  Nikon has great lenses, and I like that the shutter body does everything I want and more.  The 18-55mm lens that I purchased with the camera does everything I need, and whenever I want to upgrade, it will be nice knowing that I just need to get the lens and it will connect to the camera.I would love to write a more exhaustive review, but I'm unfortunately a novice and would not be able to describe the camera fluently.All I can say is I love it and it works great!

Reviews.Title: Bought the one lens kit from Roberts LP and I LOVED IT
Reviews.Author: Alfonso
Reviews.Content: This is my first DSLR camera, I'm amazed by its quality. 10/10 with Roberts LP and AMAZON! I did a LOT of research (about 3 months of it) since I wanted to make sure that I will be buying the best out of the best according to my money range, and I'm pleased to say that I made the BEST decision. The User Manual is great, tells you everything that you need to know, it's like your wingman for the camera. You gotta love what Nikon did with this product, it has an amazing resolution (I'm talking about the 18-55 lens) and for a beginner like me, it's perfect. I will buy better lenses in the future. Oh by the way, YOU NEED TO TRY THE VIDEO OPTION, the recordings are incredible, If you have an independent band, know how to work with Adobe programs, know a little about lighting and setting a good background, this is the camera for your first professional video. Cheers!

Reviews.Title: Perfect camera for a beginner
Reviews.Author: Bryce
Reviews.Content: My wife & I have never owned anything other than our phone cameras... (I know, we're on the young side). From all the reviews, we chose to purchase the D3200 for it's ease of use, and ability to shoot higher-end pictures. We went on a trip 2 days after opening the package, and were able to take some AMAZING pictures without knowing how to use the camera much.I would recommend this camera to anyone, especially beginners.

Reviews.Title: My first entry level SLR
Reviews.Author: HJ
Reviews.Content: I did a great deal of research before finally choosing the Nikon D3200.  In addition to the megapixels, it had a few more improvements over the D3100, and I decided I was willing to shell out the extra dollars for the improvements.  I've only had my camera for a month.  I have no prior experience or knowledge with things like aperture, shutter speed, ISO, etc.  I'm slowly learning through research and playing with the camera.  I had read this camera was great for beginners, because the LCD screen is very visual as you are making changes.  For example, when changing the aperture, there is a circular image that gets smaller and wider showing what you are doing, etc.  The product came with the standard 18-55mm lens as described.  I haven't really used the lens much as I purchased an additional lens when I purchased the camera.  I've read the lens is a good beginner lens.  As you learn more about how to use the camera, you'll eventually desire other lenses.  The camera comes with the rechargeable battery and charger, a camera strap that says NIKON and a lens cover.  There is as small built in flash that you manually turn on and off. If you are new, take the time to read the instruction manual and then get on the internet and read, read, read.  It might seem very overwhelming at first as you hear terms and numbers that you don't even kind of understand, but once the basics click you'll open up a whole new world.  If you've been wanting to invest in a camera, I can't imagine you would regret this one. There are reviews all over the internet that confirm this is a good, quality camera.

Reviews.Title: Can't go wrong with a Nikon and the D3200 is just plain fun and easy to use.
Reviews.Author: Randall G. Rich
Reviews.Content: I did a ton of research on cameras in the $400-$600 range and the Nikon D3200 just came out on top. I have been a long time Nikon user and have a number of their higher-end DSLRs and they work, they take great photos and are made to last.  They only drawback which is minor is the lens that comes with it, is good and takes nice photos but with a good lens like the 17-55 f2.8, wow ... you can really see the power of the sensor in this camera.  I bought two and with my $1200 lens, it is better than my D2X and D300, better color, saturation and overall sharpness.

Reviews.Title: Refurbished ???
Reviews.Author: Harvey M. Smith "BarrysDad"
Reviews.Content: Item looks and behaves NEW.  I received the camera and wouldn't have believed it was "not new" had it not come in a "Refurbished Product" box.  We all have our dreams. . .  especially when it might come to digital cameras.  Without the "Refurbished" option, I would still be dreaming, rather than actually shooting.  The results are not binary -- like with a disk writer (i.e., no coasters) and I have taken a few "sucky" pictures, but it was my not the camera to blame.I've gone beyond pure automatic (which is wonderful for simple "point and shoot" things) into both shutter and aperture priorities so that I can better understand its properties.  I've had no problems.  If I tell the camera that I want a wide aperture so that I have limited range of focus, it obeys -- and obeys admirably.  Haven't really tried shutter priority on any speed-involved photos, though.  Just wanted to make sure that it would understand my commands and obey -- it did.The D3200 with 24.2 MP more than meets my current needs.  I'm a former professional (film) photographer who is making a re-start on a previous profession, combined with a change to digital from film.  Frankly, I'm actually a little scared.This camera provided me with the option to get off the sidelines and into the game.  Without the price benefit from "refurbished" and the "model or two back" I'd have never been able to get here.  Thank you Nikon (and all the others who helped to make my dream begin again).Bottom line (in case you haven't guessed already) I highly recommend this product.  You won't go wrong.

Reviews.Title: You can't beat it for the price or quality
Reviews.Author: EVOLUTION
Reviews.Content: Great camera that does everything a starting SLR should do. I shopped around a bunch and read various reviews for cameras in this price range and the Nikon is perfect. I looked long and hard at the comparable Canon camera and when it came down to clicking the buy button the Nikon won. Once you get used to the feel and working with a SLR camera over a simple point and shoot i highly doubt you will ever go back. It takes little to no time to take good looking photos using the simple auto mode and getting the focus where you want it. After the simple stuff makes sense the depth of this camera starts to make sense. If you are new to SLRs this is the camera for you. If you are a seasoned photographer I bet this relatively inexpensive SLR would still impress you.

Reviews.Title: very glad I  "downgraded"
Reviews.Author: gotscience?
Reviews.Content: Sensing that Nikon had exiting new prosumer cameras in the pipeline I decided to sell my D7000 and D300s before their used prices plummeted and got the D3200 the week it came out.While I miss some of the dedicated buttons, bracketing, and the availability of a true battery grip (the ones that exist require a short cable between the port and the grip, making ergonomics lousy) I do NOT miss the weight of my previous cameras.Picture quality is outstanding and even the little 18-55 turned out so great I left it on most of the time during a four week trip.Using superb f2.8 lenses I had outstanding results at concerts, church services, indoors and outside.I'm especially happy that the HDMI output allows a clean feed to my Blackmagic Intensity Extreme and my Macbook Thunderbolt for video capture. And if you're just filming to card you now have more options and 20 minute runtime. Battery life is good but only half of the D300/D7000.The experience convinced me to keep it for now while I jump ship and switch to Panasonic GH3 Micro43. The reason I'm keeping the D3200 is its outstanding low light performance which the M43 systems, at this point, can't deliver.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for the Price
Reviews.Author: L. Milligan
Reviews.Content: This is a wonderful camera for the price. While it looks almost the same as the D3100 on the outside, it's a whole new camera on the inside. Greatly improved video. Various feature improvements that I'm sure everyone knows about, and of course, a 24 megapixel sensor.  My biggest concern when deciding to buy this camera was noise - however, Nikon has done a great job on this sensor coupled with the new Expeed 3 processor.  Noise is LESS than with the D3100 and it "only" has 14 megapixels.  It is MUCH better with noise than the otherwise fantastic Sony A65, also with a 24mp sensor (and better than the A77 as well). Dynamic range is better than the D3100 as well.Yes, it still lacks some of the bells and whistles you expect to get with pricier camera bodies, and certainly noisier than full frame sensor cameras, but that's a whole different ball game. For the price nothing else can touch this great little camera at the moment, in my humble opinion.  If you're buying an entry level Nikon at this price point it might be a toss up between the D3200 and the D5100 now that the latter has dropped in price. The D5100 has more operational features, an articulating LCD panel and similar video, but the D3200 has 8 additional megapixels of resolution and somewhat better dynamic range with very similar noise profiles. While some people many think 24mp is too much or unecessary, I love it. Detail and resolution with a decent lens is fantastic and gives you many more options for cropping, printing, etc. You can produce amazing results even using the Kit Lens with a little care. Nikon has shattered another barrier with this great little camera and I couldn't be happier with it.

Reviews.Title: Nikon D3200 is Great!
Reviews.Author: John Gagliardi "johngags"
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Nikon D3200 as a replacement for my older Nikon D70 and I am not disappointed! This camera "navigates" like my older Nikon so I did not have to relearn anything in that regard. And the newer features were very easy to learn. In fact, I took the camera to Europe for 3 weeks only days after it's arrival and was perfectly comfortable and proficient with it immediately!The autofocus is outstanding and super intuitive. The speed in which I can take rapid, multiple shots is amazing and the overall feel and weight make the camera very comfortable to carry for long periods and to use quickly!

Reviews.Title: Good entry level DSLR
Reviews.Author: jnx7 "jnx7"
Reviews.Content: D3200 is a good entry level camera. 24MP may be too much at this level, however. Even when using a prime lens (35mm/1.8 in my case) I can still see noticeable softness when viewing images at 100%. Even more so when using the 18-55mm kit lens. Still, there is more resolution in images under ideal conditions compared to the D5100, which I also own. Overall I prefer the D5100 images for sharpness, dynamic range, colors and low light noise.One other thing I noticed with my D3200 is that the VR on the kit lens can introduce blurring of images. Shooting at 55mm and 1/100 shutter speed (which Auto ISO and auto min shutter speed option will select and should be considered sufficient to eliminate camera shake) causes shaking which is visible in images. Only when switching VR off that blurriness is gone (this also means I can hold the camera steady enough). Also, I could observe the same with the 55-200mm lens at 55mm. So I don't think it is a lens issue. So I will keep VR on the kit lens off when shooting in good light. For the 55-200 however this is more complicated as at the 200mm tele end the VR switched on seems always better.Edit: upgraded the rating to 4/5 stars since there is a workaround to the issues I found. Also, I didn't want this review to be seen as negative.Update: The image softness at 100% pixel level is caused by the in camera jpeg processing. I just developed some of the RAW/NEF images taken with the 35/1.8 lens in good light and low ISO and they come out clear and sharp at the pixel level (with a little extra sharpening applied). Also there is more detail in areas of lower contrast from the NEF developed images compared to the jpegs from the camera.

Reviews.Title: With some exploring, it's fantastic!
Reviews.Author: A. L.
Reviews.Content: I had been shooting 35mm B&W; for some time, but wanted to get a little more modern system. It was a jump from 35, but the D3200 is fantastic. I'm getting great details and vibrant colors after just a little time shooting. The images are clear and crisp from 100 to 3200 ISO/ASA with slightly noticeable noise around 6400.One thing to note is that, if you don't know how to completely utilize the camera, the images will be bad, or underwhelming. I recommend trying to familiarize yourself with some of the slightly more advanced features. After using a completely manual 35 I had no problem diving into some of these features and they helped a lot. Try to stay away from the auto features and go into shutter priority, aperture priority, and manual shutter modes.The image effects are present, but I wouldn't say any of them are particularly impressive. Yes you can give your image a sort of older appearance, but if that's the kind of shooting you go for regularly, I would recommend just using an old camera and some expired film.I would recommend this camera to most people who are looking at entering the DSLR market. I take that back. If you'rte looking to get into DSLR, this is a great choice. One note, just because the MP is twice some other cameras, doesn't mean the pictures are twice as good right away. You need to get comfortable with changing settings you normally would just leave alone.I know I listed some negatives, but it still gets 5 stars because it's good at what it does. If you're filming, spend $600 on a video camera, and you'll be pretty good for the civilian market.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Byron Veasey
Reviews.Content: I spent many hours researching what DLSR camera would be best for me as a beginner at digital photography.  This one received many good reviews, so I waited for a deal with a warranty plan as well.  The plan is cheaper than with other vendors and the camera was very competitively priced.  Thanks to everyone who takes the time to write reviews, it helped me make an educated decision.

Reviews.Title: Best DSLR for the money.
Reviews.Author: Peter Haight
Reviews.Content: Although I know my review will fall between the other high-rated ones eventually, I thought i'd share my positive experiences with this camera.PROS:-Price. $500 is cheap in comparison to other similar (albeit lower quality) cameras, like the Canon Rebel T3i, 60D, or even the newer T5i.-Build Quality. This camera is built in Thailand to the extent of my knowledge but the quality control on mine is absolutely incredible. Doesn't feel cheap or flimsy. Has nice grips and a comfortable weight to it. Not an overly bulky camera either.-Image quality/sensor. At $500, you get a true 24.2 megapixel DSLR camera. SnapSort in their comparison of the D3200 vs its direct competitor, the Canon Rebel T3i 18 megapixel DSLR, stated that the image quality on the D3200 is over 20% better as attributed to the D3200's 10% larger image sensor and higher true megapixel count, which accounts for 30% more detail in photos. The image sensor is very high quality and this camera consistently takes incredible pictures. I'm not a professional photography by any means, this is simply a great hobby of mine, but I am a perfectionist about pictures. The ability to easily take awesome pictures with this camera is second to none.-Ease of use. I am am amateur photographer who was looking for a nice upgrade and I made sure to do my homework when it came to selecting a camera. I ended up on this camera because of what everybody else said, it's ease of use was a major selling factor in the purchase. I've had this camera for a few weeks and I still haven't even figured out everything it's capable of-- there's quite a bit! But the guide mode helps you with some basic and advanced photography.-Nice lens kit. Out of the box I'll admit the 18-55mm is quite limited in what it can do, especially as somebody who enjoys macrophotography, but it'll be able to do most of the shots you'd like to take. The VR feature is nice as well.-Nikon brand quality. As always, Nikon has delivered a high quality product. I've owned a few Nikon products before and they've never failed me. I prefer Nikons to Canons in the world of DSLRs anyway.-Ability to save as JPG/Raw.-Out of the box: comes with body, lens, strap, battery and charger, etc.CONS:-I can't really seem to think of any that aren't dumb little nitpicks.Final thoughts: This camera is perfect for the beginner and good enough for the master. It does it all!

Reviews.Title: Great inexspensive DSLR
Reviews.Author: Jim Millman
Reviews.Content: This is the most bang for the buck when it comes to DSLR Nikon cameras. I have many more expensive DSLR cameras than this and this is the best for the money and than some... It shocked me how light this actually is... The 3100 is as good as the 3200 is and a little cheaper...

Reviews.Title: Nice entry level camera
Reviews.Author: greg lee
Reviews.Content: The Nikon d3200 is a great entry level dslr camera. It is fairly easy to use and it takes sharp images due to the 24mp processor. I am very happy with the Nikon d3200.

Reviews.Title: Nikon D3200
Reviews.Author: Roger Spriggs
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research before making this purchase, even buying a book on the camera so I was somewhat familier with the controls and features before it arrived. I have a lot of experience with film SLR's and was amazed at all of the features available on this camera. Basically it's sold as an entry level camera and can be use as a point and shoot camera and produces great pictures in this mode but it's also capable of operating in semi-manual and full manual mode so it will produce great pictures from the time you get it, through learning to get the most out out it in manual mode.The manual is very basic, as an entry level DSLR it should be much better, I am glad I bought an independent guide book.I was concerned about it being all plastic but the material seems solid and does not look cheap. The kit lens doesn't seem as sturdy as my old Pentax SLR lenses but it works well. Overall this camera represents great value for the money, it is compact and light. I would definately reccommend this to anyone consiering a first DSLR camera.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic for what it is
Reviews.Author: J. Levin
Reviews.Content: For capturing pictures of "life" (things that are moving, people, pets, sports) a DSLR is really what you need. Buying a high end DSLR body is kind of a silly thing to do for most of us, because they become outclassed by newer technology so quickly. For example, this this is better at 90% of what it does than their highest end crop sensor models were only 3 years ago.So... if you need a DSLR for the shooting you do, this is a great option. 24mp is silly, but doesn't hurt high ISO performance too much. The AF performance is pretty good. You'll certainly do better with a 5000 or 7000 series model, but not that much better. The image quality in the right hands is pretty great, especially at low ISO.With the new firmware, the battery life has been fantastic for me. Last night, I shot 650 RAW images at a party, with the camera on (but LCD off) for nearly 6 hours straight, and with 500+ flash firings, and the battery status never dropped below the full three bars! I was pretty shocked. Tip: set the "auto info" setting to off, to avoid the LCD coming on every time you depress the shutter halfway.Also, this model is a wonderful size. It's about as small as it can be without compromising handling, and it's very lightweight. I don't mind carrying it nearly anywhere I want a non-pocketable camera. I use the 35mm 1.8g af-s prime lens on it nearly all the time. With a lens hood and protective filter (I like the Hoya heavy duty high definition protective filter), it's safe to use without a lens cap for long periods of time.One gripe: They limit the functionality of the camera in some silly ways. Maybe the worst offense is that they limit the use of the fn. button to four uses. On the higher end models, you get way more choices. For example, last night I wish I could have had an easy way to control the flash compensation, but it's a cumbersome process within menus. If this were an option for the fn. button, it would have made my night a lot easier.

Reviews.Title: I like it, but was a greater fan of the D60
Reviews.Author: Tiffany Hartman "Tiff"
Reviews.Content: There isn't much more I can say about this camera than what has already been said with regard to positive comments.  It is indeed a great camera and probably much more than the typical person needs.  I wouldn't recommend this camera to someone unless they are a hobbyist or budding professional because unless you are one of these, chances are you are going to throw it in auto mode and not give it the dignity it deserves by exploring its incredible capabilities.  In that case, I'd tell you to save your money and stick with a point-and-shoot because you'll probably get the same result since today's point-and-shoots are becoming quite advanced in their technology.  Based on what I understand about all of the specs, this camera is very similar to its upgrade which is the D5200.  It has a DX sensor as well.  It seems to me that unless you're a hard-core professional (and/or you really want the FX sensor), this camera has more than what you need and it's a great price (I paid $1,200 for the D60 kit back in 2008.  The D60 is an older version of this camera).The reason I did not give the D3200 5 stars is because I am comparing it to the older D60 that I have used for the last 5.5 years.  My husband and I updated from the D60 to the D3200 a couple of months ago.  The first thing I noticed is that all of the pictures were darker than what I was used to seeing with my D60.  I have gotten into the bad habit of using the LCD screen rather than the actual histograms to gauge exposure so at first, I thought that since the LCD on this camera is unusually bright, perhaps it was giving me inaccurately exposed previews of the photographs I took.  I turned down the screen's brightness a notch or two and learned more about histograms.  Still, the photos were dark once I viewed them on the same computer I have been using for years.  I checked the exposure compensation on the camera and it was at the factory setting of 0, so it wasn't like it was in an accidental negative setting without me being aware.  I switched into auto mode to test myself, thinking maybe I was doing something wrong.  Same problem even in auto.I typically shoot in aperture.  I am familiar with lighting.  I am saying that when shooting "wide open" outdoors on a sunny day, I am sometimes having to use a 200 and even on occasion, 400 ISO setting if my exposure compensation is set at 0.  If I use a 100 ISO setting, I have to turn up the exposure compensation to compensate.  With my D60, shooting outdoors on a sunny day (and sometimes even a cloudy day) with a medium f stop, a 100 ISO would occasionally be a bit too bright.  I am trying to understand if the D3200 is just mechanically different and I need to get used to majorly boosting my ISO or if there happens to be something wrong with my particular camera and if so, I'd like to know so that I can return it to Costco within my 90 day window.  If anyone can help me out with this, I'd appreciate it.  I have searched exhaustively online and have seen very little about chronic underexposure with the D3200.I am aware that the sensor on the D3200 is slightly smaller than that of the D60 and have considered that this may be the issue.  If it is, I am very disappointed because there is a significant difference between the two as far as lighting is concerned and in this case, I would say that Nikon has regressed rather than improved its entry-level camera.  I read that although the sensor is a bit smaller, it is newer so should still perform just as well if not better than the D60's sensor, but I'm not so sure that this is true.  I have to work considerably harder with the D3200 to get the same image that I could quickly take with the D60 without a second thought.  I am afraid to say that this has knocked the "fun" wind out of me and the camera has been sitting around without use for longer than is normal for me.Also, if you are purchasing this camera in order to utilize the wifi feature, I would discourage you from doing so.  This was the main reason we updated and the wifi adapter simply does not work.  We tried it with both an iPhone and an Android  for several hours at a time.  The adapter shuts down your ability to change settings with the camera while in use.  The moment we opened the app, the camera would take a picture (it is not supposed to do this until the remote shutter release button is tapped on your phone).  It would then begin uploading our unintentional photo and in the process, the wifi would disconnect.  This process eventually drained our battery in the middle of our Christmas card photo shoot.  We had to charge it for an hour and put it back in the camera before it was fully finished because we were losing daylight.  We tried again and had the same result so we resorted to using the old-fashioned timer method.  We were never able to take even one intentional photograph using the wifi adapter.  I love Nikon and am loyal to the brand, but the wifi gimmick is a crime.Anyway, if anyone can help me with the underexposure issue, I'd be very grateful.  I have been able to find little help with this online.  Most people tell me it is operator error but I have checked myself a thousand times and I have been a hobbyist for 5.5 years.  After months of using this camera, if I was doing something wrong, I am pretty sure I would have caught it by now.  I even read the user manual cover to cover and am still in the same boat.  Being familiar with Nikon for nearly 6 years, and at this point in my investigation, I'd say it is highly unlikely that it is me.  In your experience, does the D3200 underexpose compared to the D60?  If you can tell me if you have noticed the same thing or not, I'd really appreciate it!

Reviews.Author: Edward L. Bailey
Reviews.Content: This is a nice camera for the money. The pictures are "good" with the stock lens. Mind you if you are willing to make the investment into some aftermarket lenses, this camera rocks big time! I have added a really nice Nikkor 40mm lens that takes amazing pictures compared with the stock lens. If you want a step up from the point and shoot world - the stock lens is great for taking those kinds of pictures. The nice thing is you can invest into better lenses and also take some really great shots!!

Reviews.Title: Short But Sweet
Reviews.Author: E. Lee Zimmerman "Trekscribbler (NCC1205)"
Reviews.Content: Like so many others, I fancy myself a bit of an amateur photography.  I had stayed away from SLRs mostly due to price, but I'd always wanted to pick one up.  Well -- after much research -- I finally did, and this was it.  I used it for the first time on a trip to Hawaii, and I can't be happier.  Again, I'm no expert, but for this budding young photog, the Nikon D3200 is exceptional.  It's extremely easy to use -- though I will admit to picking up a Dummies book to get myself up-to-speed -- and would appear to be very reliable.  The pictures (at 24MP) look fabulous!  Highest recommendation!

Reviews.Title: Bought For my Wife's Birthday
Reviews.Author: mhoff
Reviews.Content: My wife absolutely loves this camera. The picturers are amazing on it and the features are a plus. A great camera to definitly have and would be a great starting point for people just getting into DSLR's. I would definitly buy this camera again.

Reviews.Title: Last camera I will have to purchase
Reviews.Author: Martin Pecci III
Reviews.Content: You can buy a Canon, you can buy a Sony. But look no further when you buy this camera. In my opinion you will never have to need another one. It has great features and absolutely the best quality for the price.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for beginning photographers
Reviews.Author: Kat Mahoney "Savvy : Digital : Frugal Geekmom"
Reviews.Content: I'm a journalist/photojournalist and my husband just got this for me for Mothers Day. It is practically attached to my neck 24/7! Between being a photojournalist and a mother, I am always taking pictures of something. I'm often afraid to go out without it because I might miss something! The instructions are very simple and the out-of-box usage is very user friendly. You can immediately begin taking photos and look like a professional. I absolutely love this camera, but I do need to get another lens for extreme close-up shots.

Reviews.Title: Great First-Time SLR
Reviews.Author: Mehan
Reviews.Content: This is my first SLR and it is great!  It takes wonderful pictures with or without flash and in the dark as well as brighter settings.  I got a refurbished one, and it works as if it were new.  It didn't come with a usb cable, but once I told the seller, they sent me one.  I love the depth of field!  I recommend it for those seeking slr's around $500 and beginner photographers!

Reviews.Title: great image - easy handling - wireless OK
Reviews.Author: F. L. Junior
Reviews.Content: I use to think that one expensive $400 compact camera would have a image somewhat not so worse than one regular DLSRBut after this D3200 I realize that there are 2 worlds, and the image from this camera is way better than every expensive top edge compact cameras arroundSo if you like photograph and like me have small kids, go for it and buy one dlsr, so you use it in childrens parties, in home and in places were you can take it ( its very big and anoying to carry but worth it in some cases)In places where you cannot use it, because its big, use some regular compact high iso camera (I suggest the 3D W3 fuji for sunny places, as a thrird camera)The wireless is nice. Somewhat slow to connect, but works nicely in my android phone and is funny to show to friends in partiesWell built camera, feels strong, and after all, I cant believe it costs so few, because of what it isAnd better of all, you can just point and shoot, and never have to read its mannual if you dont want to...Going now to buy one flash, by nikon mostly because of the brand printed in itThe only downside is that this camera was that it uses only original nikon bateries ($ 70 each), as D7000 can use regular chinese inexpensive batteriesNot anymore - after post this, I went on ebay and amazon and relize that chinese guys managed to produce non branded batteries that work with D3200, for something like U$10 to 15 plus shipping. Nice

Reviews.Title: D3200 is D Bomb!
Reviews.Author: don hall
Reviews.Content: Nikon D3200 is just about perfect!What I don't like is the nose smudge on the review screen!What I do like is everything else! Light! Fast four frames per second, beautiful 24.2 mp pics.Yes, You will love the 24.2 mp especially for cropping those big Blow Up pics of mountains and sports,landscapes and family fun times! Yes, the guide (instantly available)for novices helps get you started if you are a novice and provides enough hints to enable manual "training wheels" ... what is not to like?The Battery is even lasting for a good long while. I did buy the 1250ah for a great price to round out a perfect Amazon Nikon offering!Nikon kit lens is even very good for everyday shooting - clear, crisp and fine pictures.I recommend the Tamron 70-300mm lens for good inexpensive lens to carry in the bag.

Reviews.Title: Nikon D3200 is a 5 star camera!
Reviews.Author: Brian McKee "TBC Editor"
Reviews.Content: I replaced my Nikon D40 with a new D3200 about a month go and have not regretted it. The D3200 has some advanced features over the D40 that make it easier to use and it also seems to have more accurate exposure metering, especially when in the "auto" mode. I like the fact that the infrared remote shutter release that i used with the D40 also works on the D3200. The camera is light weight and compact for a DSLR, so it is well suited for hiking and biking. The photos are superb! Very sharp and crisp! I only wish it had a timer which would take a photo every so many second or minutes, etc. It has excellent build quality and feels good in your hands. It is well worth the money, which is very reasonable. I do not care for the "Live View" feature. This camera carries on with the traditional Nikon quality and I highly recommend it!

Reviews.Title: My new D3200
Reviews.Author: C. Gill
Reviews.Content: I've had my D3200 for about 2 weeks now.  What a great camera!  Easy to use, excellent pictures, good feel in the hand, all around great..  I have had a D80 for about 6 years now (also great).  It was time for a new one.  Since I'm not a professional photographer I typaclly use the 'Auto Mode' and always get good results.  Anyone looking for an entry level camera should look into the D3200.  There's not much you can't do with this camera.  It'll make you think you are a Pro....

Reviews.Title: Rapid Fire
Reviews.Author: Kris Carlson
Reviews.Content: This is the first time i have spent this kind of money on a camera. I know that there are more photos taking on the new i-phone than ever in history of photography but, I wanted a real camera. And what a WOW. worked first time out. easy to operate, it does not take a fast learner to make it work. The Nikon hit all the must on my list, FAST, fast enough to catch that bird before its gone. SHARP focus, it focuses its self and makes a whole lot of adjustments to lighting, and distance. BEAUTIFUL RESULTS, the pictures are great time after time. Pictures that i would have missed i get and get great.

Reviews.Title: First DSLR-Montrose, Colorado
Reviews.Author: Hiddentreasurebargains
Reviews.Content: I was not sure which camera to purchase.  We were going on a 17 day trip (road trip).  Mountains, Yellowstone, Canada, Whale Watching, pacific coast highway.....I wanted a good one but I didn't want to spend a ton.This camera was great, it taught me the basics of photography by reading the manual (10 minutes).  It was easy to use.  It had auto focus and manual.  I also purchased a 55-200 zoom lens.  After my trip I upgraded to the 18-300mm....I recommend this...as during my trip I had to constantly keep changing lenses.  Now I have an all in 1 lens!Great camera!

Reviews.Title: Photograhy and Videography
Reviews.Author: Gumper Van Lier "Gumper Van Lier"
Reviews.Content: This is my first time purchasing a DSLR. The Nikon D3200 is all you need as it produces beautiful pictures with beautiful color and sharpness. I'm just an average guy who likes to take both pictures and videos. I am not a professional photographer. All most people will need is the kit lens that comes with this camera and to shoot at the smallest picture size and the lowest quality JPEGs. The photos come out great despite the small size so they quickly can be uploaded to Flickr, Facebook or Picasa, etc. They print well too. No need for 24 megapixels. What makes this camera stand out is the fill flash; that is, when using the flash, this model automatically knows how much flash you need and your pictures come out great. This feature alone makes this camera worth it's money.I've learned to come out the auto mode and use the program mode which lets the camera do most the things for you.As for video, well, this type of camera is not the best for that. The quality is good but it can't focus fast enough and the lens makes a lot of noise when doing so. You can press half way down on the shutter and it will refocus and it will automatically adjust for light but this type of camera cannot zoom automatically so it cannot film like a camcorder. The sound is uncompressed which is great, but only in mono. It cannot film at 60 frames at 1920x1080; only at 1280x720. You should always film at 60 frames as it comes out much smoother and later can be edited using software and reduced to 30 frames if you wish.I've used ultra zoom cameras for years and currently have a Sony HX100V digital camera. It makes great videos but I was disappointed in the photo qualily which produced an "oil painting" like quality when looked at closely.So, yes, I would highly recommend this camera for photography but I am going to hang on to my Sony ultra zoom for video use. So a low end DSLR for photography and a ultra zoom for videography. That is my recommendation.

Reviews.Title: An excellent camera, an adequate kit lens.
Reviews.Author: Norman L. Hente
Reviews.Content: This is a very good camera with terrific resolution (24 megapixels). An ideal entry level DSLR camera. I just wish that the kit lens was sharp enough to take advantage of all those megapixels. I did also purchase a 40MM F2.8 Micro Nikkor lens to do some copy work and this lens seems to be tack sharp when used with this camera. I am still exploring and learning all of the features this camera has to offer but my present feeling is that the camera deserves the five star rating with the caveat that it could be even better with a higher quality lens (read expensive!).

Reviews.Title: A lot of value for the money
Reviews.Author: AH
Reviews.Content: The D3200 is a brilliant camera for intermediate to advanced users. Beginners can of course use it too due to the pre-programmed shooting modes.Besides the pre-programmed shooting modes it is literally loaded with advanced features which is a huge advantage for the experienced user.The Info screen gives quick access to often used setup items like image quality, white balance, release mode etc. and the programmable Fn button on the left sideon the front gives quick access to setting the ISO (by default).So don't get fooled by the low price, this is really a great camera with excellent output and I would say that it could easily be used by professional photographerswith a good lens mounted (at least as a backup camera).I have owned several Nikons including the D700 and my conclusion is that you can't go wrong with this camera, but be aware that the image files are quite largeespecially if shooting NEF (raw).

Reviews.Title: Nikon D3200
Reviews.Author: Mike L
Reviews.Content: The Nikon 3200 is a special treat in the Nikon lineup. The 24.2 sensor is usually found in the much more expensive Cameras. The guided settings prove to help in unusual environments were you don't have time to experiment. Bought this for my wife to replace our well worn D70. Very nice improvement and the 1080 HD video is a welcome addition. Even better my all of my lenses work with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Excellent product
Reviews.Author: Andreina Casique
Reviews.Content: 100% recommended! I'm very happy with it! Camera arrived in perfect condition as detailed in the description. The color is beautiful and had all accessories.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Jay Smith
Reviews.Content: I am a novice to SLR photography. We bought this puppy with the standard 18-55 lens plus a 55-200 one, tripod and a bag. The photos just in auto mode are magnificent in color and focus. Cannot complain at all and will highly recommend to a friend. Awesome.

Reviews.Title: love it
Reviews.Author: allen
Reviews.Content: just love it..it works great..easy to use for a newbie to camras..takes great looking pictures.thanks for your timeAllen

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Al Laney
Reviews.Content: This camera meets and exceeds my expectations. I chose the Nikon D3200 because Consumer Reports rated it as a best buy for digital camera beginners. Since receiving the D3200 I have used it almost every day. The camera was easy to use right out of the box. With just a cursory reading of the instruction manual I was able to master most of the controls, i.e., the info buttons, the settings menus, etc. While I'm primarily taking pictures in the automatic mode, I'm learning to use the other features and feel that I will soon become comfortable with them.I was surprised with how little the camera and 18-55mm lens weigh as compared to my 35mm film camera. Again, I am very pleased with this camera and will be upgrading to a more advanced Nikon model in the future.

Reviews.Title: Great package
Reviews.Author: Rick Gayman
Reviews.Content: Great camera it is user friendly great for beginner or for the experienced photo nutt. For your money you can't go wrong.

Reviews.Title: A great camera for an amateur!
Reviews.Author: Angela Moffitt
Reviews.Content: I wanted a camera to take pictures of my kids.  This one has rapid shutter release allowing me to capture them in action.  THe higher power zoom lens lets me get up close at evens without having to sit on the front row.

Reviews.Title: Nikon D3200 is an awesome camera!
Reviews.Author: Ramzi Ari
Reviews.Content: All of its functions are easy to understand and use.  My family and friends are impressed with the products look.

Reviews.Title: love my camera
Reviews.Author: leatrice
Reviews.Content: I have been waiting forever to get this camera. I originally wanted black and got red instead BUT color isnt a deal breaker... I'm happy with my purchase and this camera is truly great for my beginning stages so great my boyfriend bought one as well

Reviews.Title: just what i was looking for
Reviews.Author: nb45ti "country garden"
Reviews.Content: I like the weight of this camera.  Takes wonderful pictures.  Easy to understand for someone upgrading from a point and shoot camera.  Really enjoying shooting with it frequently.

Reviews.Title: Excellent DSLR
Reviews.Author: Ghostbuster
Reviews.Content: I remember buying some of the first DSLR's when they came out and they were a pinhole box compared to this baby. Things have come a long way and the D3200 still stands out of the crowd. Fast, light, incredibly responsive and just all around easy to use. The image quality is INSANE! Every detail or my my landscape or portraits is captured in perfection. WARNING do no not take "nudes" with this camera, every pube and freckle can been seen in high definition and for some people this could be detrimental to their self esteem. Other than than that, cool camera!

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Unknown
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera. Easy to operate yet offers the challenge of manual operation. Photos are crisp. Just an awesome camera.... I love it.

Reviews.Title: amazing camera package for price
Reviews.Author: Loaf
Reviews.Content: All around great camera package for the price-body, two lenses and high quality bag. It may not be a "professional" grade camera by definition but picture quality it a amazing. I chose non-vr lenses after much reasearch and so far do not regret it.  The camera is user friendly for simple use in preprogrammed modes and has seemingly endless shooting possibilities in manual mode.  For me it's a simply can't miss. You will not be disappointed if you are looking for a spectacular general everyday use slr. I will say it is better than my brother's Canon equivalent.

Reviews.Title: So far so good.
Reviews.Author: H.
Reviews.Content: I'd been in the market for a camera for some time, researching, reading, talking to family and friends. I ended up buying this one after another model I wanted ended up being sold out. I'm new to the hobby of photography, but its always something I wanted to learn more about.  So far the camera is performing very well, its fast and does a good job of taking photos, it has a fair amount of settings that I really need to learn, but so far the auto setting is doing a good job with the photos, I got some beautiful shots of local snow covered mountains, so the photo quality seems quite high to me, I was able to resize pictures to a more manageable level and still keep the resolution.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Product
Reviews.Author: sameer sahare
Reviews.Content: No problem with my piece. I am using the camera from last one year. excellent shots. good for beginners and family

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera
Reviews.Author: BlackPudding
Reviews.Content: Although my son previously owned an Olympus for his underwater pics (he's a scuba instructor) he researched and decided on this camera which I bought for his birthday in February.  He's delighted and thinks it's the most professional camera for a regular user and I have no regrets with the purchase from the reports he's been relaying to me.

Reviews.Title: Fun!!!
Reviews.Author: Tanya
Reviews.Content: I am VERY partial to the Nikon family.  I have been trying to decide which one to upgrade to for quite awhile and finally decided on the D3200.  I have loved it!  (When I can get it away from my teenage son.)  The features are great!

Reviews.Title: Gereral Question for previous buyers
Reviews.Author: Kevin
Reviews.Content: I have purchased this D3200 and the lens just comes rolling around in its own little cardboard box in a plastic bag within the main box is this normal? Or should I be concerned, I returned the first camera for this reason and really don't want to... Thamks

Reviews.Title: Best entry level DSLR so far
Reviews.Author: Carlos Juarez
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love this camera. I am an amateur photographer and I decided to go for this camera about six months ago. I heard a lot of good reviews and decided to buy it. I fell in love as soon as I got it. It's really small and light and really does perform splendidly. For an entry level DSLR it has al lot of he features  higher priced models. Image quality is great, and there is a variety of accessories and stuff you can do with it. I absolutely recommend this camera to anyone looking to buy their first DSLR. it's really  to learn with and doesn't disappoint after you start to get experience.

Reviews.Title: This is a great camera.
Reviews.Author: Cameron H.
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for filming video. I've used it in several locations and I love the fact that it is so light and can take full 1080p/30 video clips. I also recommend buying an external audio recorder if you are going to be taking video, because the onboard mic isn't the best.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic
Reviews.Author: Lisa S. Neal
Reviews.Content: I am a beginner photographer and I absolutely love this camera.  It is perfect! I would defiantly recommend this camera to other beginners.  I had a hard time deciding between this camera and the Canon Rebel SL1, but I am happy with my choice.  The Nikon has a slightly between picture quality than the Canon Rebel SL1.  The Nikon is also a more reasonable price. The camera is very easy to use and is not too big.  I just love everything about the camera.

Reviews.Title: I love this thing
Reviews.Author: Todd
Reviews.Content: I messed with a D3100 before I bought this, and I almost didn't buy this because I couldn't take a decent picture with the 3100 to save my life. I am not a professional photographer, but I understand the basics, and have been learning... and needed something to handle a couple tasks. I am a pilot and like to do some aerial photography for fun, I needed something my GF could pick up and take some nice shots while we are out flying. And also other simpler tasks like taking pictures around the holidays etc.This gets the job done, has enough advanced features to keep me busy trying things and learning about photography, good battery life, pretty straight forward to operate...  you get quality pictures for a good price. Lots of available lenses and goodies to go with it too...I read the reviews on this vs. the Canon T3... similar price range (canon being a little more expensive) and the majority of reviews favored this Nikon. I came into this neutral, no brand preference, just wanted something good for what I could afford to spend, and slightly over half the reviews I read favored the 3200 (though they are both considered to be great cameras). So I went with this one and I'm happy...

Reviews.Title: Missing Items
Reviews.Author: Josue Garcia
Reviews.Content: The camera is working properly and everything; the only issue is the fact that I did not get the CD or the manual. For a person who hasn't used this types of camera before, it makes it difficult to operate.

Reviews.Title: Excellent entry level camera
Reviews.Author: Dubblenikle
Reviews.Content: Easy to use, high quality pictures. Excellent entry level DSLR. I am new to photography and bought my wife a D3100 last summer. That is also a great entry level camera. I chose The D3200 because as a beginner I do not have super expensive lenses. The 24.2 megapixels allows me to take shots with my 55-300 lens and crop with better clarity than the D3100. The controls are easy to use. The stock 18-55 VR lens leaves a little to be desired. I would recommend a better 50mm prime lens for indoor shooting (larger aperture range).  But with a decent lens, this camera is perfect for beginners. I highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Yes it is that good...
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research on which digital Nikon to buy.  For my price range, it came down to the D5100 and the D3200.  I believe the D5100 had a few more advanced features but the flip-out screen just seemed like an accident waiting to happen.  I tend to crop my photos so the extra MP should help.  After spending 2 months with this camera I absolutely love it and know I made the right decision.  The photos rival DSLRs 2x the price.  I have not read much bad press about this camera and for good reason.  Buy the camera body then go out and buy the best glass you can afford.  I matched mine with the new 18-140mm and 35mm prime.  Cons:  Body is a little small for my larger hands  ISO in increments of 100 with 100 being the lowest  No in camera panorama  No multi-exposure bracketing  Pros:  Image Sensor  Shutter Speed  In Camera HDR  Button LayoutThere are a few more pros and cons but for the money, you can not beat this camera.  Overall a better value than the D5100 and quite possibly the D5200 IMO.

Reviews.Author: Reality Check
Reviews.Content: I am not a camera guy, meaning I didn't know how to use most of features on this thing when I started. However, I also bought the dummy's book for the D3200 and that helped immensely! This thing is fantastic and once you get the hang of it, after a day with the camera and the book, it is very simple to use. The continuous shoot is a blast. We took over 130 photos of the kids in just 5 sled runs down a small hill in our yard - so many goods ones and the action and image is extremely crisp.I wanted a little more zoom for capturing wildlife too, and though the lens that came with it just wasn't powerful enough for those types of close-ups, so I ended up ordering the Nikon 55-300mm lens kit also which is just what I was looking for. However, don't just buy the Nikon 55-300mm lens, that was $400 on Amazon, but the whole kit (also on Amazon) with a bunch of other additions was $100 less! It made no sense, but I'm glad I found it. Would definitely recommend.

Reviews.Title: Fist DSLR
Reviews.Author: BravoMaxx
Reviews.Content: This was a purchase in anticipation of our first baby. Have 0 experience in photography, but the pictures taken so far with this camera have been awesome! I have a youtube channel and this camera has really blown me away as far as video quality. I have attached a Rode Pro shotgun microphone for video purposes, but the stock mic is actually very decent! I have barely scratched the surface as far as what this camera can actually do and i'm already very impressed with the return for our investment.  Can't wait to take baby pics!

Reviews.Title: I lOVE my Nikon
Reviews.Author: H. Pitts
Reviews.Content: I can't say enough about the great pictures I get with my Nikon. I would classify myself as an eager to learn amateur photographer. The beautiful red exterior is just icing on the cake.I recommend purchasing the "For Dummies" book if you are new to SLR photography.

Reviews.Title: very nice camera
Reviews.Author: gary
Reviews.Content: very nice camera for being an entry level dslr, also it takes very nice sharp pictures so anyone looking for a good beginner camera id definitely recommend this to anyone

Reviews.Title: A great choice for an amateur.......
Reviews.Author: Andres
Reviews.Content: I am not a professional but I like to take pictures with good image quality and the price is worth it for the amount of pixels and the camera quality is great overall..... maybe with a better kit lens I can venture a little more than I'm used to ...

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: brittydarncute
Reviews.Content: When I was considering cameras to buy I held my breath for about 2 weeks between the D3200 and the D3100. But, I ended up with the D3200 and I love it! The D3200 is one of the best cameras that I have ever used. It is lightweight, durable, and takes beautiful pictures. The options on the camera are great and very user friendly. This is definitely a step up from the D3100 because it has the ability to take more  photos per second (action) and the higher mega pixel count gives it phenomenal color. The resolution of the screen on the D3200 is so much better as well. The higher megapixel count also allows the photographer some room to crop the photo down if necessary. To boil it down:Pros:-More frames per second capability than the D3100-More Megapixels (and bang for your buck)-High resolution screen-Lightweight and durable-Fast processor (no more waiting for your pictures to process with your old point and shoot)Cons:-Doesn't have a focus motor built into the camera -- meaning to get auto focus you must purchase a lens that has a motor in it. Nikkor lenses with AF-S or AF-I in their names.-With larger telephoto lenses it can be a little bit off center when you hold it, but that is to be expected because telephoto lenses are heavy by nature.-Not a full frame sensor but a great value for the price.I would definitely recommend this camera to anyone who is will to pay a little extra and get the quality. If you have a bigger budget however, definitely choose a camera that has an autofocus motor in it and a full frame sensor with no crop factor. Overall, this is a great camera for the price!

Reviews.Title: Great for moms
Reviews.Author: Tabatha L Vick
Reviews.Content: Super quick start up and pretty easy to use without having to read the whole manual first.  Great for moms with fast kids.

Was a little disapointed in higher iso's but it gets the job done I am a web designer and got it because I was sick of begging for content now I just stop in take a couple hundred of high quality pics charge them and get to work. As a side note if it wasn't for the sub par camera on the nexus phones I never would have gotten this. Also buy the prime 1.8 35mm lens it makes a world of difference and was only $200 more. I am not a DSLR fan and could never go back to a point and shoot

Reviews.Title: Nikon Camera
Reviews.Author: Cheryl A Harris
Reviews.Content: I love taking pictures with the camera.  It is easy to use and I plan on using it a lot.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: D Noble
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera. It was a gift to my wife, so I wanted it to last. We have had it now for 6 months and it works great! No Problems. Shipped fast too.

Reviews.Title: Very nice camera
Reviews.Author: Pamela
Reviews.Content: I bought this for a backup body for my Nikon D7000.  The D7000 only has 16MP and the D3200 has 24MP, but the D7000 has many more features than the D3200. Reviews.Author: Reggie
Reviews.Content: I can't say much more about this unit than has already been said. It is a beginner's dream. I have learned so much by having this camera that would have been such a struggle with any other camera as a newbie. I have already taken some fantastic photos, and videos are not bad as well. Reviews.Title: Fun and Excited

Reviews.Author: Honey Bee
