Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: Steven A. Switzer
Reviews.Content: Review of the Nikon D3200So far, I am impressed with this camera.I just got it a few days ago, and I am already putting it through its paces, consulting the manual, which it has both a short user guide in hard copy and a PDF format full manual on CD.  The short manual and the full manual cover most of the same things, but the longer version has more detailed information about some features that are only briefly touched on in the shorter manual.  (The short hard copy manual has 77 pages, whereas the full manual on CD rom has 228 pages.)  The PDF manual also has copies of the manual in various languages Chinese, English, Spanish, French, Japanese, Korean, and Portuguese.  In my package there was also a short hard copy manual in Spanish.  There is also a Guide Mode in the camera itself which has pointers and tips as to how to use the camera.I have already taken a few pictures and a short movie with it and I am very impressed with it so far.  This is a very nearly professional camera for a mid level camera.  And I am sure a professional could use it without any problems.  With a good lens, a pro should be able to shoot excellent images with it.Until I got this camera, I was quite happy with my 5 megapixel Sony F717 camera.  It was indeed a great camera and I took plenty of pictures with it.  And it had quite an array of features of its own, and it was quite near the quality of a professional SLR camera.  But then it started developing memory errors and finally the camera simply died on me after 10 years of faithful service.  I could not power it up, even though I bought another power adapter for it.  So I decided it was time to get a new camera.  I always liked the Nikon cameras.  And I have an old Nikkormat manual SLR 35mm camera, which I took thousands of great pictures with.  So I decided to gamble with Nikon again and upgrade my digital camera.  I wanted a good high res camera so I opted to get a 24 megapixel camera.The camera is little different from a standard film SLR camera.  You can do practically anything with this camera that you can with a manual or automatic film SLR -- and some things that you can't with a regular film SLR.  And you can get some really great images with this camera.  The camera is capable of creating images of resolutions up to 6016 x 4000 pixels and as small as 3008 x 2000.  (My old Sony digital camera by contrast took pictures of 2560  x 1920 maximum size.)  That translates to a size of 20.1 x 13.3 inches or 50.9 x 33.8 cm at 300 dpi.  Of course you can enlarge the image even further using a computer with image editing software such as Paintshop Pro, or Adobe Photoshop, and there would be no pixelation, and obviously you can also edit the image in other ways and add special effects, etc.It has a standard viewfinder that all SLR cameras have where you can see the image as the lens sees it, but if you like to use the digital monitor, all you have to do is press a button and then you can see the image in the digital monitor.  But if you use the monitor, it is a good idea to use it in low light such as indoors.  Those types of monitors are hard to see in sunlight.  Movies however can only be shot using the monitor.One great feature that I love with this camera is that it can do both movies and still pictures with the same camera.  It takes high quality video at 1920 x 1080 maximum and 640 x 424 minimum.  You can take stills while shooting a movie too.  And it can shoot up 64 frames per second.  And you can adjust settings such as f-stop, ISO, and other settings to get the best movie images.  To shoot video in stereo sound, you need a special stereo microphone.  It has a standard micro audio in jack, so you can hook any microphone to it including stereo microphones.The camera has a built in flash, but also supports hot shoe for external flashes.  There is no jack for using flash with cable however, unless you have a flash cable that uses the hot shoe, or some kind of remote control flash.Because I had old lenses that I used and were compatible with my old manual 35mm camera, I wondered if they would work with my digital camera.  And, yes, they do work.  I have a wide angle Nikkor lens, and a 200mm Rokunar zoom lens, and both work with the camera, that way, I don't have to buy new zoom lenses or wide angle lenses.  Of course, because these are manual lenses, you have to do everything manually such as focus, and f-stop, but they work.  So if you have a good high quality lens from a manual 35mm Nikon or compatible camera, you likely could use it.  And as one commenter in this forum put it, and as any professional photographer will tell you, the lens or the "glass" in the front of the camera is one of the key ingredients to getting great crisp sharp pictures with a camera.  The digital image processor, which is the digital equivalent of film is the next ingredient.  And as far as I can tell, this seems to be a high quality image processor.Like any professional SLR camera, you can vary shutter speed manually, anything from long time exposures (such as for night city lights or stars), to 1/4000 of a second (for high action photography).  It also has ISO ( or ASA) settings which adjusts the sensitivity of the internal image processor to simulate film light sensitivity.  Normal standard film is 100 ASA or ISO, but if you are in a low light setting and need to simulate a higher speed film, so that you can shoot in low light levels at higher shutter speeds and small f-stops, you can set your ISO setting to 400 to simulate 400 speed film or set to 1000 ISO (ASA) to shoot indoors in low light without using flash and you can use higher f-stops and/or faster shutter speeds and still capture good images.  It goes up to a whopping 12800 ISO, great for night shooting in very low light.  But, like real film, the higher the ISO or ASA rating, you may get grainy images or "noise" in your images, and color gets washed out in low light levels.  Of course, I mentioned f-stops and these are adjustable too.  If you are using a manual lens, you will have to adjust manually, and f-stops vary according to the individual lens.  Some lenses have f-stops from 1.0 and go up to f 22 and even to f 64  (F-stop, by the way, for novice photographers, is also called aperture opening, this sets the opening in the iris, or the eye of the camera.  It is very much like the pupil of the eye. The higher the number, the smaller the opening.  Hence, with a low f-stop, you have a wide opening to let in more light, but also less depth of field, that is, the range of distances where objects will be sharp.  The higher the f-stop the less light, but greater depth of field.  Thus getting a properly exposed image means finding the right combination(s) of film speed, shutter speed and f-stop. )Of course, if you are just looking for a quality but simple point and shoot camera, this camera has a fully auto mode, which will handle everything for you, f-stop, focus, and shutter speed.  All you do is point, look through the viewfinder or use the monitor to frame the image you want, push the shutter release button just lightly to allow the camera to focus and adjust settings, and then it will beep, push down, and click, it will take the picture.  (But then, of course, you will have to use only the fully automatic lenses with the camera.  You can buy additional lenses separately.)  The camera will warn you if your image will be underexposed, and in auto mode, the built in flash may pop up.  There is a built in light meter, but it only works with the automatic lenses, but if you are shooting manually with a CPU lens, that is a lens that can be used fully automatically with that camera, the light meter will be of great help in getting good exposures.  After you take the picture, the monitor will show you what your image looks like and there is a menu where you can browse your pictures and even do some editing and even delete bad images.  No more waiting days for your film to come back from processing, and then you see if you made a mistake!  If you don't like the image you took, you can change the settings and shoot another image until you get it right.The camera has everything a novice photographer would need to get started.  There are also special automatic settings that the camera has to shoot specific subjects easily, such as a setting for portraits, settings for shooting children, settings for action and sports, automatic settings for low light situations, etc.So this camera covers a range from professional photographers to rank amateur and novice photographers.Other features include, burst shooting, where you can shoot a rapid sequence of images up to 4 images per second such a for capturing dynamic action.  It has a timer for self portraits or situations where you may want to wait a few seconds before shooting the image.  There is a white adjust so that light looks natural in different kinds of light, such as florescent light, sunlight etc.  Some automatic lenses also include features, such as image stabilization to avoid the shakes in video and motion blurs in stills.The camera body seems to be a fairly solid construction and fairly rugged.  It is a solid molded plastic with rubber grips.  Of course, you wouldn't want to drop the camera because of all the electronics, but the body seems to be a fairly solid molded exterior.  It has a good ergonomic feel and is a less clunky and is somewhat more lightweight than my F717 camera which had the trademark long lens.The camera takes a variety of SD format sticks.  If you don't have a compatible card reader on your computer, you can use the USB connection to upload your pictures to your computer.  Depending on the size of your stick, image size, the level of compression you use, and whether you are shooting movies or stills you can store anywhere from hundreds to thousands of pictures or several movies of 20 min length on your memory stick.  I bought a 32GB stick which can store thousands of pictures without having to change sticks.  It sure saves on buying film!  After you upload, you can then delete the images and movies off of your stick, if you desire, to make more room, especially if you shoot a lot of pictures.The camera in the box comes with the camera body, the lens that is advertised to come with the camera depending on the camera you buy (and that is a fully automatic lens.)  A shorter booklet manual, CDs for the PDF version of the manual, which is the longer manual, the charger, a L -ion battery, a neck strap, and basic software for handling, importing, and editing your images, movies, etc., and a couple of small odds and ends, such as lens caps, viewfinder cover (if you are shooting without looking into the viewfinder, to prevent light leaks).  If you have Windows 7, Vista, or XP, you can actually access the images and movies and move them without any special software, but the software simply makes it easier.  If you have a compatible memory card reader or USB connection, you can simply use windows utilities to read the files on the stick.  They are just ordinary *.jpg and *.mov files.  There are no proprietary formats or any special data types for which you have to use the provided software.  If you shoot in uncompressed format, the stick will then store .nef files.By the way, if you want to do things like double or multiple exposures and special effects, that is all doable with image editing software such as Paintshop Pro or the more popular and well known Adobe Photoshop.  Hey, this is digital photography!  You don't need to do them with your camera.  But the camera does have some effects you can add during or after you take the picture.  And the software included with the camera can do some basic image editing, but it is not a full fledged image editing software package.This is my review so far.  I will provide updates as necessary.

Reviews.Title: Very Easy!
Reviews.Author: Thomas Escritor
Reviews.Content: For a beginner, this camera was very simple to understand and operate. Having used canons before, this Nikon was a breeze. All that's left is to get new lenses and accessories and I'll be set!

Reviews.Title: a great purchase
Reviews.Author: Michele Kennett
Reviews.Content: It is aa very versatile camera allowing the photographer to use auto settings, or manual......I really love it, it's user friendly, too

Reviews.Author: J. Hutchins
Reviews.Content: Hey I am a Nikon user from my first Nikon the FM-2 then my F-3/T and the N8080 conventional cameras. Then my first digital the D100 then the D200. So I wanted to get another digital, I was looking for more megapixels, would have like to have the DX-4 or the D800e but not on my budget. I am not really interested in the the HD Movies, but I see that they are all offering that feature. Looked at them all and was looking at price and megapixels. After seeing the specifications for the D3200 I was impressed. I know that everone has preferences and I am sure I will get my share of comments but I am very happy with this camera. My only issues are that it is really light and you really need to hold it firm. I am still getting used to the focusing system it not like the D100/D200. I processed some test photos and I really like that 32 Megapixels. You can really see the fine details as you zoom the image, even in the low res .jpg files.

Reviews.Title: Love It.
Reviews.Author: twinpeaksr
Reviews.Content: Being our first DSLR did a lot of research before selecting the D3200.  When the price dropped and Coke spilled into our Point and Shoot the time was right.Have been playing with it for about 10 days, the menus were pretty easy to figure out once I learned about basic camera settings.  The Auto setting produced some of the best pictures I have taken, though considering what I was using before that may not be saying much.  Did not play with the guide mode, thought I would but we dove directly into the Manual mode which forced us to learn the settings.  The adjustments took reading the manual to figure out, but once we learned them they were easy to adjust on the fly (ISO, Shutter Speed and F-Stop).  As we worked through the settings, we were able to improve our skills and see the D3200 really shine.  Seems to take excellent low level light shots, and high speed action seemed to be no problem.  The detail was great on all the shots.The setup menus were easy to figure out, thought they were quite intuitive.  Also the build quality is great, it was smaller than expected, but fits in the hands well, and has a solid feel.  The rear display looks great and is a good preview.  Data through the viewfinder was also easy to read and great as we learned how to adjust settings without using the info page.Overall I would recommend it.  Through all the research I found that the more knowledgeable people were who reviewed it, the more they found that they complained about.  Now that I have it in hand, I realized that while what they are saying may be true, this is an entry level DSLR, and to the target audience, it does not matter.  Enjoy the Camera!

Reviews.Title: My first DSLR, I am very satisfied with the body and the price for the kit
Reviews.Author: Matthew Glinski "Software Architect"
Reviews.Content: This camera is admittedly an entry level DSLR with no official battery grip support and very few hardware buttons for manual shooting. Regardless, it is an excellent platform for high quality lenses and is compact enough to come with me in my bag. I have had excellent results shooting in lots of lighting conditions. The raw photos are excellent too, very much worth the price of entry. This is a great body to save a few hundred on and spend the money where it really counts, on high quality lenses.

Reviews.Title: Amazing!
Reviews.Author: Nick
Reviews.Content: This camera is freaking incredible! The image quality is incredible and you can basically shoot any image from far away and still create an up close blown up version of the image and have the quality still be incredible!

Reviews.Title: Love it!  Worth it!
Reviews.Author: GoCards!
Reviews.Content: I'm nearly a week in to owning the Nikon D3200 and after a lengthy hiatus from SLR shooting I can't imagine a better way to get myself reacquainted to photography.  The 24MP is overkill for most, true enough but for some of the enlargements I plan to do it works for me.  I personally think the D3200 is a bit beyond an "entry level" classification so instead I'll call it a "Pro-Wannabe".  Or perhaps a "Second-string Pro".  Focus is pretty fast, shoots pretty fast and pics come out great.  The detail on enlargements is remarkable.  Quality photos can be had on auto right out of the box.  The menu is great too both of which will get newbies into the action rather immediately.  I shoot largely in the program mode and dabble in the other priority modes.  Switching settings is pretty quick with the info button and the programmable function button helps that much more.  I presently have it set for quick ISO changes.  Indoor shooting without a flash is quite good and I haven't really hit any readily visible noise until ISO 6400.  I'm still shooting with the kit lens but can't wait to put a 50mm/1.8 on it!  The current reduced price along with the free SD card really made this a deal for me.  In my opinion you can't go wrong with the D3200.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Camera!!
Reviews.Author: Gablud
Reviews.Content: I have been using this camera for over 2 weeks now and I am more than satisfied with the quality of the images even in low light condition. While I am still learning the features, each one surpasses my expectations as I kind of get familiar with it. The only slight dis-appointment was additional 60 bucks for the wifi adapter..an in built feature would have been absolutely wonderfully.

Reviews.Title: Perfect
Reviews.Author: artígrafo
Reviews.Content: Is the perfect beginners DSLR. Good functions, resolution and the better: The Expeed 3 Image Processor. This camera is very easy to use.Perfect time with One-Day Shipping. I ordered the offer with 55-200mm lens and free 16 Gb SD Card. But they arrived me in 3 packages from different origins.

Reviews.Title: Love it like a brother, my brother.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Love it.  This camera takes amazing photos.  As a beginner who's previous photography experience has been limited to point-and-shoot digital cameras the quality and depth of photos I've taken with the Nikon d3200 are superb as one would expect from any single reflex lens camera.  What sets the d3200 apart, in my opinion, is the Guide mode which not only allows you to select the effect or style of photo you want, but also explains the settings on the camera to achieve that effect.  The d3200 also shoots full 1080p video and has a wireless remote feature that can be operated via smart phone (which i also have and love as well, but that's a separate review). 5 stars/5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful Red Beautiful Pictures
Reviews.Author: C. Saxon
Reviews.Content: I held out for the red and I'm glad I did.  It's a beautiful instrument to look at.  A surprise for me was the built in diopter adjusting knob by the eye piece.  My eyes are weakening and this helps a lot.  I shot pictures of the kids by the pool with the included 18-55mm zoom and the pictures were sharp and beautiful.  I bought a nikkor 35mm 1.8g lens and it allows great indoor shots without the flash,if desired.  I had considered the Canon t4i but the reviews were so so and they apparently removed some features that were on the previous models (my son has the t3i and loves it).  I highly recommend the d3200 for its ease of use and outstanding picture quality.

Reviews.Title: Little Princess
Reviews.Author: Jay™
Reviews.Content: I am not comparing D3200 with any other camera since tons of such comparisons and detailed product reviews are freely available by now, including the DxO Lab one.Things I liked about this camera:Small, light weight, fast and delivers straight out of the boxComfortably fits into mine, my wife's and son's hand (Personal choice)Great image qualityExcellent colorGreat detail, especially when that 24 MP turns in our favor (by using right lens and technique)Very good video qualityI had checked the specs before I placed the order and hence I already had an idea about what is there and what is not there as far as features are concerned. Investing on a 35mm/50mm prime lens is worth considering for no-flash shoots at low light.Overall, Nikon D3200 is an excellent DSLR

Reviews.Title: Happy I stayed with Nikon
Reviews.Author: Picture taker
Reviews.Content: I've had other Nikon cameras in the past and when it was time to step up to a new one I selected Nikon once again. I've always had good performance and no problems from the older Nikon's and this is even superior. This is a simple to use camera with all of the features I had been looking for. I suspect Nikon will be the brand the next time also.

Reviews.Title: New guy to the DSLR world, great camera to start and grow with
Reviews.Author: Shanner
Reviews.Content: I guess a Pro guy may say it is a toy camera, but I like toys and this is perfect. Clean design, feels and looks solid, and lightweight. All these properties was a big deal for me, and being able to operate with one hand in auto mode if needed is nice. This DSLR is my first after working with working digital point-and-shoots for nearly seven years, and although I do have a photography background, I am pretty clueless when it comes to more advanced photography. The Nikon D3200 is making it very easy for me to learn, however. This model is nice because although it is good for a beginner (the auto modes are super straight-forward and offer beautiful images), it clearly has features that more advanced photographers can use as well, and with a little bit of practice, they are easy to pick up on.I took this camera to a friend's wedding a few weeks after I purchased it (I got it in May 2012, wedding was in early June) and received so many compliments on my pictures because of it. I even had a few people tell me I should consider taking up photography as a side job. Of course, I'll leave that to the professionals, but it's nice to know that my camera can produce such quality photos that people think I'm a master ;).While I wouldn't recommend this product to a person just getting started in photography (an $800 price tag is a big much--stick to point-and-shoots until you get the basics down), I would highly recommend it to those wanting to take a step into the DSLR world who want to increase their photography capabilities by more than they can even imagine!

The red enamel is very  nicely done, I usually am a black fan on camera's -but something about this one drew me. You need a SD card, I went with a 16GB which will do a thousand pictures at high resolution. I also bought a macro-zoom lens, took a picture of one of our cats and zoomed the image using the button on the back -to the point where the entire lcd showed just a green eye-and it wasn't taken as a close up-the whole cat was in  the image taken. I imagine the capability to zoom and crop with 24 megapixels will afford the capability to make pic's that were a little off, quite usable. First DSLR I have owned, I have had some large zoom fixed lens point and shoot units and just wasn't happy with the pictures. You can make adjustments that mimic changing film speed in a 35mm SLR. This is making photography fun again like it was with my old  SLR film camera

Reviews.Content: Bought for my daughter to use in photography class. Very nice, lightweight. Good controls. She loves the red body, really makes it distinctive. Replaced a Nikon T3i with this and very happy about the trade.

Reviews.Content: You really cannot go wrong with this camera. I purchased this along with a Nikkor 55-300 VR II lens. Reviews.Title: New DSLR user
Reviews.Author: Rayneman5
Reviews.Content: Recently purchased the D3200 as my first DLSR. This camera is easy to use and comes with good instructions. (Nikon has some great information for this camera online.) The auto selection works in most applications, but having the ability to switch to a particular picture mode gives you greater control over your photos. The reviews indicated a short battery life, but I have yet to run out of battery while shooting during the day.(Note that I did purchase a spare battery just in case.) The stock 18-55mm lens is OK, but I find that I would like to have an additional lens for upclose as well as a telephoto for distance shots. Note that with my poor eyesite and shaking hands, I sometimes have to take advantage of the VR feature. That along with autofocus has come in handy in a few instances. Though a few pictures did not turn out as expected because I was focused on the wrong object while taking a shot.I would not recomend this camera if you are someone looking for a high quality "point and shoot". But if you have some basic photography skills, and can learn how to use this camera beyond its basic set up, then you would benefit from purchasing this particular model. Some of my photos have amazed my friends and family in ways I did not expect! :)

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera, going to be a great entry DSLR
Reviews.Author: Jeeper "Jeeper"
Reviews.Content: I recently bought the D3200 and have run a couple hundred images through it.  Long exposure night shots have been great, both with the kit 18-55mm lens and the Tamron 70-300mm lens.  I wish it did have some effect modes like the point and shoot cameras have as well as other brand DSLR's (IE sepia mode, etc..) That can also be done in post processing though.  The software that comes with the camera also seems to work great for some minor post processing work, especially just shifting white balance and things.  I picked up a wireless remote and corded shutter release at the same time as well as polarizing and UV filters.  Focusing could be a little faster, but at this price point I am not complaining.The camera itself is very light, so a large lens throws it a little off balance.My biggest complaint is the optional wireless adapter.  I bought it because it said you could use it as a shutter release.  You cannot use it as a shutter release if live mode is active, and you can only use it to trigger the shutter, you cannot use it to do a long exposure in bulb mode.The app is also a little flaky, if you let your tablet/phone go to sleep while you are transferring photos from the camera it cancels the transfer.  I installed an app called "Wake Lock" from the Google Play to keep the tablet awake, once that was done images transferred fine.I hope to update this as I get to use the camera more.

Reviews.Title: A Very Good Easy To Use Tool For Taking Very Good Pictures
Reviews.Author: Robert Nuttmann
Reviews.Content: I have been an avid amateur photographer since I was young.  For many years I used various 35mm cameras and one medium format one that take film.  I took thousands of slides and pictures.  When digital started with Sony floppy disk cameras I bought one.  I used the digital cameras with my work in heavy machines.  I graduated to more Sony digitals.  I always had high end phones, and those started having better and better digital cameras.  I never got rid of my favorite film cameras.  These include a 1953 Voightlander Prominent, Olympus OM2n, Olympus XA, Olympus Stylus.  I learned to edit pictures early on using Photoshop.  I have used Picasa since introduced.  I really like Picasa as it is OK for the thousands of pictures of machines I need to quickly edit and add to web sites.  Recently I have started using iPhoto.  iPhoto IMHO is much more capable than Picasa.I stopped using film a few years back and have started back using film in the last two years.  I started to try and get better pictures with my digital compact and phone cameras.  Those work well with scenery pictures at a mid level of quality, but were hopeless taking pictures of pets or children or any action.  When I saw the Olympus OMD in chrome I immediately wanted one of those.  Looked my my 1980 Olympus OM2n which I have always thought was just about a perfect camera and beautiful.  Mine works perfectly after 33 years BTW.  So I did months of research on the OMD and then tried to see and hold one in person.  There is only one Olympus dealer in San Diego and they kept selling out of them.  Once I got to see a black OMD but no chrome.  Then Oly started the on again off again sales.  I was pressured by going on a long trip last summer so I wanted to get a new DSLR.  This was complicated by the fact that Olympus is a smaller sensor format that not everyone likes.  No actual live viewfinder.  And it costs a lot more than Nikon 3200.The other camera I considered extensively was the Sony Nex 6.  In the past I had only bought Sony digitals and consider them a superior product.  The Nex 6 was less money than the Olympus OMD.  What turned me towards the Nikon was recommendations.  On line recommenders like Nikons.  The Sony early last summer had a limited selection of lenses like the ones I wanted.  Olympus had want I wanted, but I never could hold one in my hands and it was twice the price of the Nikon 3200.  I drove several times to the local camera store to see the Olympus, but no luck.So I ordered the Nikon and two additional lens from Amazon.  As usual Amazon delivered everything fast and in perfect condition.  The Nikon has worked flawlessly from day 1.  The 3200 is fairly easy to learn.  The adjustments and controls take a little time to get used to but are relatively easy.  It takes very good digital pictures without much effort.  Those who just want to take pictures that are pretty good should just take the standard 18-55mm lens with image stabilization and leave it at that.  It works fine for pictures blown up on my 27" computer monitor.  The only annoying thing is that with a lens as slow as this one the built in flash is always popping up.  Even in shots that don't need a flash.  So I find myself setting the camera flash off frequently.  I have not used the two additional lenses I bought much.  The longer lens a few times for distant scenery.  I thought I would use the much faster 35mm lens all the time.  So far that is not the case.  Before I bought it I did not notice that the 35mm lens did not have image stabilization.  When I have used it that has not been an issue.  I come from many cameras that did not have IS and always instinctively hold my breath and stay still when shooting.The Nikon is much larger than my Olympus OM2.  I would prefer the OM2 size.  But I find the 3200 very comfortable in my hands.  Yes it is big, but the size and weight works well.  It is a plastic camera.  It is well made but very plastic.  Much more so than my last Sony compact camera.  The Sony has a much more pleasing quality look to it.  The comparison between the Voightlander or OM2 in quality appearance and feel is vast.  In the distant past I owned a Nikon FM SLR and can attest that Nikon knows how to make a very high quality look and feel camera.  The Nikon is not cheap plastic feeling, but rubberized sorta cheap plastic feeling.  If you really like Apple products like Mac Books, iPhones, iPads you may not like this product.  It is in no way a jewell like thing of beauty like Apple products.But it takes very good pictures easily.  It focuses fairly quickly and comes up with very good color balanced shots on automatic.  It has a small view finder.  Much much much smaller and less useful than my 33 year old Olympus.  For me the viewfinder size and lack of light is the worst feature.I have most of my film cameras on display in a glass cabinet in my office.  The Voightlander is a thing of beauty.  It still works well after 60 years.  The last time it was cleaned and worked on was 1979.  It is hard to use.  Mostly because of it's small and dull view finder.  Maybe some day I will buy a Leica M3 for the finder.  The metal working and gorgeous glass lenses on the Voightlander put a smile on my face just holding it in my eye or hand.  The Olympus OM2n is only slightly less so.  The metal on the Oly is not as nice but the Olympus easy operation makes up for it.  Both the Voightlander and the Olympus are about the same size.  The Nikon 3200 as a tool to take pictures is a good camera.  The shots I have taken with it at the highest settings on the sharpest (35mm) lens are very good.  They are not as good as shots taken with my OM2 and it's 50mm lens with good film in color or detail.  However, the Nikon is much easier to use and get good shots with.  But I feel absolutely no passion for the 3200 and good photography demands passion.

Reviews.Title: Good entry level DSLR
Reviews.Author: W. Smith
Reviews.Content: I've only had this camera for a few weeks after a couple of months of research online. I am new to DSLR but have used Nikon D40 before. So this review is for novice. D3200 is a light weight, small camera that packs many features. I use it for my kids primarily. The picture quality is very crisp and clear. The 24mp thing doesn't make much difference to naked eyes, but sure is nice when you need to blow up the pictures to print. We had some portraits done by a photo studio and some pictures look blurry at 12x12. Even with my cheap inkjet printer at home, there's a difference when I print pictures from various sources.I noticed after a few days that I don't like the color saturation of the pictures. The colors don't "pop". Found out online that D3200 does not saturate the colors as much as other DSLRs in its standard mode. If you like more vivid colors, you have to adjust the image quality under Shooting Menu in one of the manual modes. I cranked up the contrast and saturation in Vivid mode and the colors came out a lot better. Some reviews complain about its tendency to overexpose, I wonder if that's what they're talking about. Kids don't look very good if they look pale.I also noticed that it performs more like a point-n-shoot camera under indoor low light while using one of the preprogramed settings. The light compensating bulb in the front is very, very bright. As I'm getting more comfortable with the various settings, I find myself moving toward the P, A, S modes. I haven't had time to use it on landscape. I look forward to using it during our trips this fall. I haven't used the video function either. Looks a bit too complicated for me. I've got a point-n-shoot camera for that.

Reviews.Author: jimbu
Reviews.Content: While the D 3200 is marketed as an entry level camera, you can also shoot in aperture, shutter  priority to advance your knowledge. With the 18-55 MM kit lens, the D3200 takes incredibly sharp  shots in many different shooting situations, and you can shoot in RAW and JPG. This is a whole lot of camera for not much money. It's good for family shots, travel, but not so great with fast, fluid action (sports). This camera performs exceptionally in low light. The image quality with the 24.2 MP sensor is rich and very detailed. If you are just starting out, there's a handy guide to tell you some techniques and ideas. Whether you are just picking up your first DSLR or you have a lot of experience, this camera is a pleasure to use. I haven't shot video yet, but when I do, if it's of use to anyone, I'll update.

If you want a camera that takes great pictures then you will be happy with this one!

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Nathan
Reviews.Content: I really wish I could get to the ISO settings as easily as I can get to the exposure and aperture controls.This really is my only complaint with this camera; beyond that it handles easily (my hands are, I suppose, average size), the flash is bright, and if you, like me, want a camera capable of taking great images without a terribly high price tag, my experience says that this is better than its competitors.  The lens is also a winner, creating consistently sharp images at all zooms and apertures.  True, even wide open at 3.5 the amount of light available makes indoor handheld photography a tad challenging, but with a little practice the settings can be reached which make it possible to achieve stunning results.Learn about the settings!  They all matter, and do plenty.  Also, learn about lenses.  They also do plenty, but can be plenty expensive if you need to get more specialty results.

Reviews.Title: My first DSLR
Reviews.Author: RajK
Reviews.Content: I bought the Nikon D3200 bundle from another retailer including 18-55 & 55-200 VR lenses and the wireless adapter. I have had film SLR and point-n-shoot digital cameras before but this is my first DSLR. I have had it for two weeks and I am very happy with my purchase.The camera body w/ lens is very light compared the film ancestors. Controls are logically placed. It offers a variety of options for the serious as well as point-n-shoot amateurs.Menu settings are easy to follow though the accompanying guide was not very  elaborate. You need to download more detailed reference manual from the Nikon USA site for more detailed help.The camera has manual(M), aperture priority(A), shutter priority(S), program(P), auto with and without flash and various scene modes. All the non-auto modes work great and offer you a lot of flexibility. I did not use the auto or preset scenes modes I found most of what I needed in the other modes.The auto-focus has a variety of options to suit various situations & scenarios (all the way from single point focus to wider area for focus. However I found the exposure metering options to be somewhat limited. The AF-L/AE-L button allows you to lock auto-focus and auto-exposure as you pan the camera. and it is useful when you want to focus on the subject on the side of the frame.The wireless adapter is a useful addition to the camera as it lets you take pictures on the camera remotely or download or view pictures from an Android phone. I only wish they had more control in terms of exposure time or aperture control in the app while using the camera in the manual mode.

Reviews.Title: Great DSLR

Reviews.Content: After using a Nikon D50 for several years I wanted a replacement with more megapixels and video capability. The D3200 fits the bill nicely. For the nearly newbie, the guide mode will help take some of the mystery out of a camera with more buttons, dials and settings than the typical point and shoot.The D3200 has several automatic settings for the typical shooting situations that will set the likely settings needed for the shot.  This will allow those of you who want a nice camera's quality without spending too much time learning speed, aperture, f-stops and the like.  Switch selectable modes include night portrait, portrait, landscapes, kids, sports and macro. The experienced photographer can configure the camera with full manual settings, shutter priority, aperture priority and the like.I find the D3200 fits nicely in my hand and makes it easy to position for the shot.  I like having the eyepiece for the viewfinder as I'm often shooting outside. LCD displays are often overpowered by the ambient light which for me is the reason to consider this camera over some of the similarly priced compact cameras. Being bigger than a point an shoot, means you'll need to plan on taking it along instead of just keeping it in a pocket, however.

Reviews.Title: OK but underwhelming
Reviews.Author: now what
Reviews.Content: Background:  I currently own two other cameras, a Pentax K-5 and a Panasonic Lumix FZ150.  In the past, I've shot with Sony, Canon, Fujifilm, Mamiya Sekor, and some others that I can't remember.  I have no brand loyalty; I will use any camera that is able to generate good images on a consistent basis.  Most of my shooting is outdoors, daytime (dawn to dusk) using burst shooting and telephoto at or near 300mm (450mm ff equivalent), but of course there are exceptions.  I do a lot of shooting in very high-contrast situations (brilliant white sunlit foam against a dark blue sea or shaded cliffs, for example).  I do a lot of cropping and/or enlarging for prints up to 20x16in or larger.My comments on the D3200 are based on expectations and comparisons with results obtained with other cameras, mainly the K-5 (using kit lenses) and the FZ150.  I also did the same shots fairly recently with the Pentax K-r (which I sold to upgrade to the K-5) and a Fuji S100FS (superzoom bridge camera with 2/3in sensor, 11MP and 14.3 optical zoom, which was great but not quick enough in burst mode), and those results also enter into my evaluation.My purpose in buying the D3200 was:1. Get higher resolution than I have with the K-5 or FZ150.2. Have something that would be a bit lighter than the K-5, while matching it in IQ.3. Have decent burst speed and depth.  (With the K-5 I shoot a lot at 7fps; with the FZ150 I alternate between 5.5 and 12fps.  All at full resolution, RAW.)Beyond this, I was going to be pretty easy to please.  I don't do much low-light shooting, and I don't mind doing PP.The good:--The D3200 is a nice camera in terms of design, pretty well laid out.--The D3200 feels good in the hand, is well balanced, and light yet solid.--The kit 55-300 lens functions well and smoothly, and is solid, with a metal bayonet mount that works easily and firmly.--The LCD is a real delight.  Very bright, good resolution and contrast, very easy to read.  (And I am a committed VF user. ;0)--Battery and memory card doors are light but don't feel flimsy; they are well designed for quick opening and closing.--The burst at 4fps (RAW or JPEG) is acceptable for many action shots, and steady.--The VR (anti-shake) works very well and hand-held full-zoom (300mm) shots are clear at 1/180.  (I didn't go below this shutter speed yet.)--AF is quick and reliable.  (In a complex physical environment, it's most effective if you select single point focus as otherwise the camera may focus on something other than your intended subject, but this isn't unusual.)--Color and WB are very good right out of the box.The not so good:--Unfortunately, at present there is no substitute battery available, so you must pay between $40 and $50 for a Nikon battery.  Both Pentax and Panasonic also charge a lot for their batteries, but other totally acceptable options (which I have as backup) are available for a fraction of the price.--Another drawback is the NEF Raw format used in the D3200.  Unless you have CS5 (or maybe CS6) or equivalent, you can't process D3200 NEF images in Photoshop.  (You can process earlier versions of NEF, but NEF keeps evolving.)  Luckily, there are free programs like Raw Therapee, Irfanview and FastStone which do read NEF from this camera.  Of course, there is also NX2 (Nikon PP software) which you can download off the internet or from the CD with the camera.  It's a good program for  improving image IQ, but lacks layers and other features found in PhotoShop.  You also can convert to Adobe DNG (which is read by PhotoShop and other programs); the free DNG Converter may be downloaded off the net.  Be sure to get Version 7.1; earlier versions will not work with D3200 NEF (I found this out the hard way).--There are a couple of shortcomings in the controls, but most of the main functions are quickly accessed and changed by pushing the "I" button on the lower left of the back of the camera (below the lower left corner of the LCD).--The camera has an irritating eagerness to make you use the LCD to view your settings.  It would be nice to have full information easily accessible through the viewfinder, instead of having to take the camera away from your eye.  Example: to switch to and from burst shooting, you have to use the LCD screen to make changes; when you push the burst button (which is a very nice thing to have), the only change menu appears on the LCD, not in the viewfinder.--The D3200, like many other cameras, has a tendency to overexpose.  This is easy to remedy by setting EV at -2/3 or so.--Leave the in-camera sharpening on; images are very soft without it.--Bracketing, histogram, DOF preview: all missing.  These aren't fatal flaws, but the rest of the camera had better be very good to compensate.The bad:--IQ is a major disappointment.  I have a number of standard shots that I take with every camera I try or buy; I have done this so many times that I have a very clear idea of what is possible and what reasonable expectations are.  Again, I'm comparing this camera specifically with the K-5 (16mp on an APS-C sensor, kit lens 55-300mm) and the FZ150 (superzoom, 12mp on a small 1/2.3 sensor).  Recent experiences with the K-r (12mp, APS-C), the Canon T2i (kit zoom lens) and the Fujifilm S100fs (11mp, 2/3in sensor, bridge zoom camera) also enter into my appraisal.In every one of my standard shots, the D3200 performed worse (in terms of IQ) than the K-5 (and K-r) and often worse than the FZ150.  When shooting at full zoom, definition was poor and fine details were often fuzzy or smeared.  With in-camera noise reduction turned off, noise was often evident.  With either of the other two cameras at full zoom, you generated an image that allowed you to count the roof tiles on a house well over half a mile away, and read license plates at 400 to 500 yards.  The K-r was the same, and the Fuji S100 was close.  The D3200 does not have this capability.You might say, well, sure, it's probably the fault of the kit lens.  But my K-5 has a kit lens, and the FZ150 itself IS a kit lens, as was the Fuji S100fs, and they all did better on the same shots.  At any rate, the D3200 doesn't seem like a hot enough camera to warrant spending serious money to put top-quality glass on it.  And again, the K-5 didn't require this, nor did the K-r.You might also say, well, yeah, but who shoots all day at 300mm?  I don't know, but why limit yourself right from the start?  If the camera/lens combo can't do this, I'm going to miss out on a lot of shots.Apparently, I'm not the only one who is underwhelmed by the images from the D3200.  Here's what dpreview had to say on the subject: "resolution and detail aside the Nikon D3200 has no image quality issues of note."  Hardly a ringing endorsement of the camera's IQ.Bottom line: the purpose of making pictures is to get good results, and the main ingredient is IQ.  I will take a couple of days to try some adjustments and see if I can get better results, but if it's this much harder than it is with my other cameras, I'm not optimistic.IQ is closely related to pixel size; in general smaller pixel size can be detrimental, and the D3200 has pixels that are quite small for a DSLR.Larger pixels offer enhanced light gathering ability and a higher signal-to-noise ratio.  Higher pixel counts on the same size sensor create a tradeoff.  To use one common metaphor that equates pixels to light-gathering "buckets," having more, but smaller buckets (pixels) on the same surface area (sensor size) doesn't mean you can collect more water (light).  In fact, the shape and necessary circuitry of each pixel create wasted, non-light gathering areas in addition to generating electronic noise.Here's how Wikipedia puts it:  "The size of the image sensor, or effective light collection area per pixel sensor, is the largest determinant of signal levels that determine signal-to-noise ratio and hence apparent noise levels ...more pixels within a given sensor area will make the image noisier."Here's a comparison of pixel sizes for a number of DSLR cameras.  The D800 is a full-frame, 36mp camera; the others are APS-C (a generic term which includes slightly differing surface areas and proportions).Pixel size in microns (µm)Pentax K-r - 12mp - 5.42 µmNikon D3100 - 14mp - 4.94 µmNikon D800 - 36mp - 4.88 µmPentax K-5 - 16mp - 4.8 µmNikon D5100  - 16mp - 4.78µmCanon Rebel T3i - 18mp - 4.3 µmNikon D3200 - 24mp - 3.85 µm

Now, the lens that came with the camera had a very noticeable smudge inside it, but it doesn't seem to affect my pictures in any way that I can see. The smudge is inside the lens, so I can't get to it. (Or at least I'm not sure how to get to it)Other than the smudge, I love this camera. I've been taking pictures of everything and everyone I can. So much so that I've been banned from most places with people in them. Now I'm stuck taking incredibly crisp close up pictures of my cat because she doesn't run away. But even if she did, this camera has an excellent action shot option so I could get a non-blurry photo of the cat's escape.If you have the money to spare, then go for a higher tier camera. I'm sure the results from that would blow your mind even more than this. But this is an excellent camera for its price, so if you're in the market for one then buy this beauty.Now I shall retire back to my dungeon and take pictures of the people that couldn't run away fast enough. And you can bet your butts that the pictures will be clear enough to capture the dust particles in each of their tears.

Reviews.Title: An excellent camera but a questionable upgrade from the D3100
Reviews.Author: Ken
Reviews.Content: This camera looks and feels just like the camera it will ultimately replace, the Nikon D3100.  The major difference between these two cameras is the D3200's new Sony sensor with much higher resolution; 24MP vs 14MP for the D3100.  The LCD screen on the D3200 also appears brighter and sharper than the D3100 LCD and about the same as the D5100 (but not movable like the D5100 LCD Screen).  Notwithstanding the different sensors, the photographs taken with each camera (especially at lower ISO settings) look almost identical.  I have reviewed the D3100 seperately here on Amazon.  Photographs taken with the D3200 are richly saturated and highly detailed.  An external flash with bounce capabilities (ie SB-400) greatly enhances expsoure and color indoors.  The only quibbles I have (and this is also true for the D3100 and D5100) is the automatic white balance bias towards yellow under incandescent lighting resulting in an artificially warm look. Manual adjustment of the white balance provides better color accuracy under artificial lighting.  There is no dedicated white balance button or white balance bracketing option.  Also, the D3200 tends to overexpose quite a bit outdoors (similar to previous lower end Nikons) but doesn't underexpose indoors as the D3100 sometimes does.  The overexposure is easily fixed by adjusting the exposure compensation or by spot metering. There is no exposure bracketing option.  The AutoFocus on the D3200, like every other Nikon DSLR I have ever used, is very quick and accurate under all lighting conditions.  This camera (as does the D3100 & D5100) uses the EN-EL14 battery.  Only a battery actually manufactured by Nikon ($40+) and not a generic 3rd party battery will work.  Consequently, having a spare battery is a bit of a luxury with this camera.  The megapixel count of the D3200 may be overkill for most people especially this camera's target audience.  The D3100 14 megapixel count (D5100 16 MP) is more than sufficient unless you plan to print highway billboards. The file size of .jpg files generated by the D3200 is over 12MB (almost the size of the D40's raw files).  An advantage of these larger resolution files is the ability to crop photographs without any issue of having a small remaining file size.  The extra megapixels does NOT improve the image quality or amount of detail being captured.  The dynamic range of this camera (the difference between the brightest and darkest part of the picture that show detail) for .jpg files is excellent and appears about the same as the D3100 and D5100 at base ISO using the kit lens (and Active D-Lighting turned on).  There is a downside to the D3200's higher resolution; a bit of increased visible noise at high ISO levels specifically at ISO 1600 and 3200.  Comparing photographs taken on identical subjects at identical conditions using the same lens at 1600 or 3200 ISO on the D3100 and D3200, shows a little cleaner photographs on the D3100 (and the D5100).  Reducing the file size from "Large" to "Normal" does improve things a bit; perhaps this setting lowers the MP count.  In this context, it would be helpful if there was more than one ISO stop between 800 and 3200 (there is just one stop at 1600) as well as a dedicated ISO button so that one didn't have to navigate through a menu to adjust the ISO.  In summary, the D3200 is a very nice camera capable of taking very sharp photographs.  Like all cameras, the most important component is the skill and imagination of the photographer.  The D3200 is not a worthwhile upgrade in my opinion from the D3100 unless you place great importance on the ability to crop a very small portion of a photograph.  The D3100 and D5100, which are both less expensive than the D3200, are simply better cameras for most people. Incidentally,  I did not use the video or live view so obviously I can not comment on these features.6-4-12 UPDATE:  Within the last day or so, CNET and Cameralabs.com have each issued their respective comprehensive reviews of the D3200.  These are the first actual reviews by a major web site of the D3200 that I am aware of.  These reviews confirm that although the D3200 has some improved specifications over the D3100 (higher resolution for sure), the image quality of the older (and less expensive) D3100 is better than the D3200.  Specifically CameraLabs rated the image quality of the D3100 18/20 and the image quality of the D3200 17/20.  Consequently if image quality and value are important criteria, the D3100 should be given strong consideration over the D3200.

I truly believe that this camera has enough functions for you to delve into and take shots that are as professionals as some of the ones that are posted here; all it takes is practice!!!I am sure if I had bought the Canon or Pentax, I would still be blown away from coming from a point and shoot camera. I really think any one of the cameras would suffice and I think it all come down to preference.  For us, it was the color "red" because we were tired researching.  If there are any suggestions I can give, I would say go find a camera and put it in your hands for the look and feel to see if it's suitable.I also want to give props to Roberts Inc. (Amazon Marketplace Vendor) for their quick delivery and service.  Roberts Inc was one of the few that had red in stock. Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: C. Dalziel "Joybilee Farm"
Reviews.Content: This is my first SLR digital camera.  It was a little intimidating when I first got it a year ago and I put it away for almost 8 months, preferring my Pentax point and shoot, because there were fewer settings.  I took this one out of the back pack again in November and determined to learn how to use it.It takes fantastic low light shots and it gives great product shots for my website using the product tent with full spectrum CFBs.  I'm a total noobie with Digital SLR, even though I used to take photos with a Pentax K1000 and develop my own film.  Digital SLR is nothing like the old Pentax.I also use this camera to take landscape shots and live animal shots.  It does a really good job with both.  Some of my landscape shots look like paintings, the focus is so crisp, and the light play with the camera is really attractive.  It has a fast shutter speed for action shots and to catch moving animal shots, like seals leaping to grab a herring out of your hand.  I haven't mastered the grandchild shots yet, though.The pictures are 6 to 8 mb in size and give lots of room for editing using the built in editing tools.  The video is good and the built in microphone is better than the one in my Flip video camera (which stopped working this Fall).The camera has a learning curve.  I'm not going to outgrow this camera for a long time.  I'd recommend getting one of the camera guides to shorten your learning time, if you've never used an SLR digital camera before.I still haven't learned how to fully utilize all the bells and whistles, but now I'm determined to learn.Buy a sturdy tripod for it.  I got an aluminum tripod and the wind blew it over in the first 5 minutes of trying to shoot a video with it.The red colour is the best.  It was the reason I decided on this camera over the alternatives.  And after a year, I still love it.

I recommend trying to familiarize yourself with some of the slightly more advanced features. After using a completely manual 35 I had no problem diving into some of these features and they helped a lot. Try to stay away from the auto features and go into shutter priority, aperture priority, and manual shutter modes.The image effects are present, but I wouldn't say any of them are particularly impressive. Yes you can give your image a sort of older appearance, but if that's the kind of shooting you go for regularly, I would recommend just using an old camera and some expired film.I would recommend this camera to most people who are looking at entering the DSLR market. I take that back. If you'rte looking to get into DSLR, this is a great choice. One note, just because the MP is twice some other cameras, doesn't mean the pictures are twice as good right away. Reviews.Title: Great Still Camera, but Mediocre Video Camera
Reviews.Author: Leslie Young
Reviews.Content: The D3200 is my first DSLR.  My previous camera is a Canon PowerShot S3 IS, which I cherished until the noise in the still photos started bothering me more and more.  I can barely see my son's face in some of the photos when lighting is not optimal.  The PowerShot S3 is a great video camera, and I got that camera right before my son was born so I could record lots of videos of him.  It has handled that job admirably.  The PowerShot does not record video in HD, however.That's when I started eyeing the Canon T3i and T2i.  After a year of shopping and researching, I decided to give Nikon a chance.  Perhaps I was partially persuaded by my Nikon fanboy cousin, who is a professional photographer for twenty years.  All the rave reviews on Nikon cameras also helped me cinch the decision.  The fact that the D3200 offers an unprecedented 24 MP for an entry level DSLR is the final nail.I am extremely impressed by the image quality right off the bat.  Having a decent lens that comes with the camera body probably makes the biggest difference between the D3200 and the S3, but I am sure having four times more megapixels doesn't hurt either.On the downside, while D3200 can record true HD videos, but autofocus capability leaves a lot to be desired.  It does not seem as responsive as the S3, and the lens motor is extremely noisy ([...]).I may resort to using the S3 primarily to record videos and the D3200 to shoot stills, which is not the most efficient system.

Reviews.Title: Good camera, but have to send it back
Reviews.Author: Igor A. "Igor"
Reviews.Content: Very good camera, a little bit small for my hands, but very light.It makes pretty good picture, no questions. Why only four stars? And why I want to return it...OK, there is a huge deal breaker for me - no FP mode. Yes, I know, it's totally my fault, I should read spec more carefully. I bought this camera in a single click after reading a general spec. I have the d90 and was interesting in more cropping ability, I don't care about video, I have a good camcorder, but I do need a better low light performance with higher ISO. My d90 is best camera ever, but I don't like to go with it above iso 400, even with ISO 400 noise is noticeable.I'm not a pro. I'm just taking pictures of my  18  months daughter, a lot of pictures, almost every day.I mostly do it at home and use sb-900 flash with various lenses. And now you probably understand why high synchronization speed is so crucial for me. The d3200 allows you to shoot with  flash using 1/200 exposure or higher (slower), it's definitely not enough for my high speed baby :-)Also, imaging you are shooting portrait against a sun, you have to use a fill flash and you also want to preserve thin DOF to get a nice blurry background, it is also impossible with d3200.About pictures quality - I didn't notice significant difference between d3200 and d90. My old and lovely d90 still very sharp. I've tried  Nikkor 50/1.8g and Sigma 17-50/2.8. In terms of sharpness and focus accuracy my 50 mm is doing better on d90, Sigma is my flagship for indoor shooting is doing pretty similar and very well on both bodies. I have not tried 18-200vr yet, I'm planning to try it over the next weekend. I also have a 60mm d macro and 105mm/f2 love to use them on d90, but they are both D and will not auto focus on d3200. The only gain that I see with using d3200 it's a much lower noise between ISO 400 and 1600 (compare to d90), but don't go higher. D3200 produces better colors and of course much more details (thanks to 24mp sensor). I didn't play with raw on d3200.Almost forgot, the face recognition is not that good compare to even some p&s;, many times d3200 focus has been jumped between my daughter face and her toys, especially balls. I also like 3d tracking in my d90 much more, it's more accurate. The d3200 is not always can predict movement direction and set focus correct in 3d mode.So, I have pretty mixed feeling about d3200. It's a nice camera and could be a perfect walk around camera, this is a good and light backup camera, this is even nice prime camera if you don't use flash much as I do. But it doesn't work for me. Just one more feature and this camera could be a champion, but no FP HSS means no deal for me.Sorry Amazon, I'm really love your  30 days return policy, It's not my usual practice, but this time I have to return this little baby, it doesn't feet my needs.Bottom line: I would recommend this camera as a first slr camera to people who want to advance their photography experience and people who like to control their cameras settings. Good luck to all of you!

Reviews.Title: Great Photos, Terrible Video
Reviews.Author: Mr Arif "sabinls"
Reviews.Content: I love the camera and I'm happy I purchased it. It's really a lot of fun to use and feels well built.I got the D3200 a few months ago. The picture quality is excellent but video recording is no good. Video focusing is the issue. The focus is very slow, and the stock lens makes a lot of noise when focusing. When I record moving people I usually resort to manually focusing the lens. Also, the D3200 also can only record 1080 at a maximum of 30fps, which is very noticeable when compared to 60fps - especially when recording rapidly moving subjects. At 30fps moving objects seem jittery and move unnaturally. Due to these issues, I use my iPhone almost exclusively for video. I didn't expect a DSLR to take perfect video, but I assumed it would be better than my cell phone. I break out the D3200 usually only in low light conditions. I also feel that the videos are soft.The extremely slow focusing has made the camera useless for recording video. Imagine this, you are focused on a subject and the person moves two feet farther from the camera, the camera does not realize this and does nothing. So, you hold down the shutter button which tells the camera to refocus. Now the camera cycles through being completely unfocused to properly focused - this gives me a headache when I watch it later. So obtrusive.The photo quality is excellent. The only gripe I have is the custom white balance - you must go through numerous menus every time you want to adjust it. I have a simple canon point and shoot camera that allows me to customize the white balance with two clicks.

Reviews.Title: Open Your Eyes!
Reviews.Author: S. Normand "Scotcher"
Reviews.Content: It is easy to get tunnel vision with all these glowing reviews on Amazon.  However, this camera really doesn't have any standout features.  Its the same old technology that has been around for years.  You are still going to have to wait a ton of time between shots, the burst mode is slow, and the burst mode does not support focusing between shots.  The view finder is not going to actually show you the picture you are going to get since it is an optical viewfinder.  And the viewfinder is going to black out when you actually take the shot.  Sure, all these traditional SLR cameras take great pictures, but really, what camera at this price doesn't.  What are you really looking for at this price point?  For me, it is fast between shots and can burst fast so I am sure to get a great shot.  I hate cameras that make me wait between shots until the camera is ready to take another picture.If you want the hidden gem in the SLR camera world, check out the Sony SLT technology.  It is a new technology that is much faster and allows the viewfinder and focus mechanisms to function like they should.  I have the SLT-A57 and I think you can tell from the reviews that it is as good or better than any of these SLR cameras.No, I don't work for Sony.  I just think that someone should point out the fact that there are other options out there and better technology available.

Reviews.Title: 24 MP ?? Must be a great camera
Reviews.Author: Shinebox
Reviews.Content: Well I ordered this camera because the temptation was too great. I already have a SONY NEX 5n and a PAnasonic GF3 and for the price i thought this camera was a great buy based on reviews I have seen on the web. I think this is a good camera for the entry level range of users who are upgrading to a DSLR. I see a lot of people boast about the size of the camera being a lot smaller then most other DSLRs and all I can say is the other cameras must be monsters because this is not a small camera by any means.I gave this camera 4stars because i think it is a very capable camera for the price and I didn't think it fair to give a lower rating because of my bias towards the Micro 4/3 cameras. I am not a professsional but I am getting into photography more and more. To be honest I didn't think the video when taken in lower lighting indoors was that great and every picture taken indoors with fairly well lit lighting during the day wasn't the most crisp pictures i have taken. I used Aperture priority without a flash and had the aperture open fully and let the camera do the ISO and shutter. My Panasonic GF3 and SONY NEX seemed to get better results. I have to say it was nice to look through a viewfinder again as my last cameras were all in a LiveView type of config.As far as the build and fell of the camera it seemed pretty cheap feeling. I had to go for the red color because i thought it was nice to have a different look to it other then black. Hey, if you want pretty picture you ned a pretty camera right? lol. It has a cheap plastic feel to it but it wasn't a show stopper by any means. I don't see myself dragging this camera to get pictures on a daily basis. More of a specialty kind of usage because of its size. The Micro 4/3 i can take anywhere more easily and it does the same thing even better.I just want to say after reading a lot of reviews on AMazon and elsewhere I truly believe that only a couple people mentioned that you can take great pictures with a point and shoot and a DSLR for everyday use. If all your doing is going around taking shots of your friends drinking beer and partying then most cameras would do the trick but if you want a night shot of the moon or fireworks or Christmas lights you will need a DSLR with all the programming modes. One other key thing i have heard people preach about photography is it's all about the glass in front of the sensor. Mostly true as a good lens can make a difference.My next purchase will be a mid range camera or high end one when I get better at picture taking. I dread trying to find a camera when I am ready, 16, 18 , 24 megapixels.. this one has external mic, this one doesn't, this one has bracketing but why did they remove it from this camera, this one has 1080 in 30, 24, this one has noise at 1600 ISO.. blah blah blah. OMG shoot me now. Too much choice clouds judgement.If I owned a camera company i would make two types of  cameras, one entry level and one Pro with all the features. It's crazy all the different models every manufacturer has out there, ridiculous.In the end I returned this camera because i like my two Micro 4/3 cameras and well.. I didn't feel that spending $600 was worth it getting a camera that does the same thing as my other two.

Reviews.Title: Nikon went too far with the disabling...
Reviews.Author: Taran Morgan
Reviews.Content: This might be the best camera Nikon has ever made (yes I own the D "single digit" bodies), but arbitrary choices by Nikon marketing have made this unusable for professional photographers.  Take for example the SC-29 cord not working...  Who on earth thought it would be a smart idea to disable the AF-assist on this cord?  How about no commander for CLS on camera?  Nikon thinks it can sell more flashes and other "higher end" cameras with this strategy, but really all it does is make the consumer angry.  Take away the IR capability in D3100, then bring it back for this camera. Why?  Nikon marketing.  Obviously everyone complained and they were forced to "add" a feature they deleted the previous year to save a few pennies.  This kind of nickel and diming by Nikon has gone too far!I understand soccer moms don't even know what an SC-29 is, I understand not everyone needs CLS, or remote capability, but to arbitrarily defeat these features in order to sell me a D7000 shows Nikon doesn't care about its most loyal customers.  Give me the option to pay for these things via firmware, like Sony, but don't just write off a perfectly good camera for professionals because you want to push me to models with higher margins.Understanding capitalism is painful to me, and product marketing isn't exactly my forté, but if Nikon continues to make dumb decisions in order to get me to buy a camera I don't really need, I won't be buying anymore Nikon cameras (and I have owned dozens).

Reviews.Title: Toyish plastic - made for a the $400 point-shoot crowd
Reviews.Author: aceducy "aceducy"
Reviews.Content: I sent it back and got the D7000 - wow what a difference.  Thank you Amazon!I'm disappointed at some of the reviewers boasting they feel they got a D800 at a D3200 price.  This is STILL a D3200, and is meant for a very large, but very neophyte audience.  Nikon knew there were millions looking for a DSLR for $500 - maybe so they could say they had one.  Well here it is, and believe me you get what you pay for.  If you believe the egos of the prior reviewers, you'll certainly be disappointed when you try take this camera out of the simple, picture-led guide mode.True, this camera is very much entry-level, but it's REAL entry level.  And the 24mp does not look like 24mp - unfortunately the way the computer processes the image it ends up looks more like 8mp.  The images are hard to describe - it's like they're synthesized or over manipulated.  Even the RAW seems compressed and lossy.  I saw a side-side close up analysis/review of the image, and although it's 24mp, most of the pixels in, say, a 20 pixel radius are all the same!  The camera doesn't have the power to distinguish the pixels for clarity like the higher end cameras.  Point and shoots do this as a matter of course, then they brag they have "24mp" etc which may be misleading some into thinking "well 24mp is still 24mp".  But it's not.  Go do your online homework and look at the analysis photos from this camera.  You'll see what I mean - and that pans out in real life.  Just one step up, the D7000 is 10x the camera, and yields much brighter photos.  It's sort of like an old round 50's style TV vs a new 90" hi res LED TV.It's plastic case gives it a chintzy feel, it's VERY slow at shot acquisition (you will certainly wait a bit till it's figured out how to take the shot), autofocus is awful even with $3000 glass, metering is whacked, short battery life you name a bad trait and this camera has it.  Oh - and don't get caught in the rain with it either.However, it is lightweight.  And to some that's quite important.  Like a tourist that has to lug a his new SLR all over creation, when they're used to a little pocket camera.  This camera is 1/2 the weight of any DSLR.And it also has a real dumbed-down "guide" that takes about 30 seconds to setup a shot - so that whole sophomoric 7th-grade level guide thing is a bust.  And the scene selector on top doesn't help at all either.  In both my wife's, my 24 yr old son, my and my Mom's use, about 30/50 shots were blurred, mis-flashed, mis-exposed to WAY out of proportions etc.  So why have 24mp for a camera that can't handle it?The lens that it comes with (mandatory) is just more cheap plastic mess.  If this camera was sold w/o the lens it would be in the $299 range.  We put a $3k lens on this camera with little improvement - it still just can't cope.  Don't fool yourself into thinking you're clever by purchasing a $4000 camera for $400.  You've got a $400 camera.But I wouldn't waste your time/money - get the D7000 and be done with it.  If you're that hard up for $$ where you can't/won't shell out another $200 for the pro camera, then go back to a point and shoot
